content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Ninja storm three does a few things right, and a few things wrong. Personally, I found it highly enjoyable. The fights are beautifully animated and are accurately described as "easy to learn, hard to master." Though there are many cutscenes, I never found them obtrusive as quicktime events tended to be woven in most of them. If you really want to play a good naruto fighting game for once, and you're not a console player, I highly recommend this game.However, I did have some serious complaints. The game is poorly optimized to work on the PC, and personally, the game runs abysmally on my system, with entire fights taking place in slow motion with the audio sync of the japanese wire-fu movies of yore. Some people might not experience this issue, but I did, so I'm making note of it. Secondly, the online part of the game is utterly dysfunctional. Online, most players can expect 2/3 online matches to disconnect before anything really happens due to server-related issues. It's incredibly frustrating, and while the developers have promised improvement, we have so far seen only one patch that did not fix the issue. In short, if you don't care about the multiplayer much, and don't mind tinkering with your system to get the game to run as it would on a console, you'll probably have a blast with this game. However, if you wanted to play online against other people and/or you're still running a system similiar to mine (I'm running XP) you'll probably feel it's a waste of your money.*EDIT*In recent patches, the online segment of the game has actually been fixed... More or less. It's functional now, more often than not, and while not perfect, the multiplayer of the game is still very enjoyable.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												I'm going to start with what I feel would be the negative parts of the game, and then end with what I liked.It's ironic when a Naruto game has filler, but a forgiveable amount, the actual anime is so full of unneeded garbage it's ridiculous. Please show the emotional and plot bulding flash backs, and get to fighting. Them standing around talking every 2-5 minutes is too much.Not to mention the actual traveling and "find" system was completely useless. I chose Legendary(hardest difficulty) and never used a shop, or used any ryo after getting the one achievement. There was no need for it. You'd have to be a kid, or really bad at fighting games to have to use items all the time. Not to mention it isn't even a battle requirement, ever. You could get by just from spamming ninjutsu and substitute.Too many cut scenes, it felt like work to get through the cutscenes to the content. It was like 5-10 minute cutsene, 1 minute battle,  another cutscene.Sad part is I need to replay it to unlock all the achieves. Not going to. The things they want are damn near impossible. Why I say that isn't even a matter of skill, or being bad at the game. The fighting mechanics themselves and some of the battles you just can't do what they ask. ie: 6 vs 2 battle, legendary, can't block forever, you will eventually get caught by some random spam of ninjutsu that you can't block, and it's a fight for health all the way through. Unless there is an item that magically makes you have 2 more HP bars or something. If the mechanics don't get you, the camera will. Many times the camera just pans inside my character or is at an angle I can't see anything and a bunch of them with guard break/get me caught up in a bunch of crap.I did like however when they worked plot into the actual fight. I hated standing around listening about what they're going to do. Unlocking more emotional parts, etc. It was really fun to play the action sequences.They mixed free roam into it, it looked nice, almost like you were running around in a real anime, but really fell short to previous games made in terms of map size, exploration, and items.There is many hours of content here, took me quite awhile to beat it completely. I would say maybe 10-13hrs of gameplay on your first play through. At a certain point I wished the game would finally end, the bits of filler in it from the show of them talking for ridiculously long times about the same thing between different characters probably made it longer than it should be, same as the show.As far as Naruto games go, I would probably give it 5/10. -Tried something different and were very creative in terms of UI and story presentation.- Very good artwork/textures, it was very fluid and felt like I was playing the show.- Easy to understand system, becomes pretty fluid by the time you end the game.- Captured the emotions of the anime really well.- Quirky- Had a bit too much talking and I felt bored pretty quickly at certain areas of the game.- Sounds/music didn't seem all that great, some audio glitches here and there. (Most of the time I didn't even notice their was music at all. If it had some original OST theme music in there, I must of missed it.)- While the free roam was a nice thing to have, I don't feel it was necessary, and I think it was thrown in "just because."Would I recommend it? Yes. Do Ithink it's worth what I paid for it? About 80-90%, it should of been about $5-$10 less.

content:
Posted: February 19
												Full Burst is a remaster of the original Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 which was released for the PS3 and Xbox 360 a while back, the improvements in the remaster are obviously visable and do make a difference. First the game is fully in 60 FPS which is important if you have some experience with other fighters like Tekken and/or Street Fighter since it's completly different to a 30 FPS game on console. Also the graphics look alot better with better effects and the better cutscenes look gorgeous especially when Kurama attacks the Hidden Leaf Village at the beginning of the game with all it's fire and bloom effects it just looks very good. The Storyline is a mix of flashback events like the attack on the Hidden Leaf Village but most of the story is set in the 4th Great Ninja War with it ending at the fight with Obito. Now the fact that they didn't include the whole story is pretty dumb considering the Manga was pretty much finished before this game was released and they didn't include the ending of the manga/anime in the game is just a means for creating another Sequel is a completly different story, but I digress.The fighting itself is awesome in my opinion on par with games like Tekken or Street Fighter, feeling-wise but also skill-wise, obviously Street Fighter is more oriented to competetive gamers than casuals but it still feels like you have alot of possibility of learning and skill involvement. The fighting features a Jutsu System which we've seen since the dawn of this series and also a Ultimate Jutsu System which is a Nerdgasm for the Fans of the original Manga/Anime. To see such Techniques as the Tengai Shinsei used by Madara and also Sasuke/Madaras/Itachis Susanoo is just awesome.Also the Soundtrack which is featured here is actually pretty good, if you watched the Anime it doesn't really feature a Soundtrack which acompanies emotional scenes but the game actually uses it's soundtrack to make emotional scenes even more emotional.It is a very good game for fans of the Anime but also for fans of other Fighters who had no experience what so ever with the Anime or Manga. But I advise to watch the Anime since the game features alot of big, crucial spoilers (which is expected).

Posted: October 26, 2014
												A really nice fighting game, with extended content as for story mode and character cast. The story centers on the anime right after the battle with Pain, voices are available in both japanese and english, directly from the tv series. All cinemas are in real time, not pre-rendered crap, and you can even compare both the episodes with the cutscenes from the game, which look fairly identical. The fighting style it's pretty much a 3D "smash brothers" like gameplay, you have fairly simple way of performing special attacks, a block button and you can move freely over the arena with smooth animations and details for each character, very fast paced fights and anybody can play it without problem.Overall, it's a nice game, specially for Naruto fans.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												I came to this game looking for something where I can dip in here and there to have a bit of fun. What I got was much more than that, providing a game that appeals whether you have an interest in the anime/manga or not. NS:UNS3FB contains the awesome drop in and play experience I wanted, providing a large pool of characters which all have their unique traits but the control setup makes them easy to adjust to. It also backs this up with substantial single player modes, ensuring that I put in quite a number of hours exploring everything the game had to offer.The battle system forgos the usual 1 on 1 fighting style for a behind character more open battle system. Control inputs are quite simple but still offer quite a wide variety of options when fighting, most of which tie into the chakra meter which you have to recharge during battle. Choosing when to unleash that ultimate jutsu or skilfully using a substitute to escape a powerful attack is great fun. Unfortunately the camera has some odd quirks, especially if you get designated as player 2.You can read a full review of this game here.[www.neoseeker.com]

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst is perhaps the most extreme example yet of Namco Bandai's attempt to appeal to the converted and only to the converted. Here's a game not simply for any old Naruto fan, but for Naruto fans who are completely up to date with the story and characters as they currently exist in the anime/manga episodes and are seeking a new way of experiencing previously explored plotlines. If you're not up to date, then not only are you going to struggle enormously with the story as depicted in the game's early stages, but you're going to ruin what you've not yet seen of the TV series. Unfortunately, due to gameplay that is as unwieldy and bloated as its title, Full Burst is not an acceptable way to get yourself up to date with this franchise.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Let me start out by saying this is a good game, it is decent. I would recomend it, but I can not because of a couple of fatal bugs and annoyances. First, the entire game plays at around 75% full speed, which is annoying, but you can get used two. Second, there is like over 30 hours of cutscenes, over 50% of the loading times is to load another cutscene, and for people like me that like to 100% games, there's an achievement for not skipping any cutscenes in Campaign. I did not get this game to watch some anime. While I like it, its not great. Third, and this is by far the worst, there is a fatal bug in the final battle, which causes the entire game to crash. Nearing the end of the battle there is a quicktime event, it asks you to press "A", and then it crashes. Many people have told the developers about this problem, but they ignore it. After battling for half an hour, when you start it up again, you have to do the entire battle over again, only to have it crash again. There's also an achievement for beating the final boss..... So, yeah. You know how the best thing to do in a game (the most rewarding to a gamer) is to defeat the final boss? I never got that satisfaction. Thanks to YouTube, though, for letting me know how it ends. I now know that this is not the final battle, and now I can say a full thanks, Naruto, for wasting over 2 hours of my life (tried fighting it 4 times, crashed all times), on a battle made to look awesome, which ends in a crappy quicktime event, and ends up with (spoiler alert) the main bad guy getting away.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												As a Naruto fan, I have to say: there's just too many cutscenes. If the story wasn't about naruto, I'd never play this. You barely get to fight 3 minutes before you have to wait 20min worth of cutscenes to play again. Also, so many useless lines! Producers need to learn from Valve how to tell a story without interrupting the game all the time. Also, the game has pretty much nothing extra compared to the manga or the anime, so no bonus story. And  you have to play storymode if you want to unlock every other character, so you have no choice. You need to go through what's bad about this game before you get to enjoy it. And they probably don't give a damn about it, since it sells easily after the story is already successful. Only buy this if it's on sale, or else it's wasted money. It's a fun game on PvP, but the storymode is a complete desaster.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												As someone who played some of the previous Ninja STORM titles, "Full Burst" takes two steps forward and one step backward... all the while having a deadweight called "online mode" clamped down on its ankle. Gameplay is broken into three parts - story mode, versus mode and online mode. Here are some highlights and lowlights for each mode.Story Mode Highlights- Multiple battles with new characters- Boss battles with quicktime events continue to be visually stunning- Has a little bit of a "choose your adventure" vibe to the storyStory Mode Lowlights- Story telling continues to be weak in distribution - subtitles are boring and most of the cinematics involve scrolling stillshots- Fights can get tedious - there's only so much variation you can do in this game- Final few boss modes are incredibly frustrating as poor camera angles ruin the fun---Versus Mode Highlights- The real star of the game, more playable characters than ever- Action continues to be fast-paced, great art direction- Adding cinematics on ultimate skill takedowns adds a bit of flair to fights- Challenge mode is pretty fun in a mindless sort of wayVersus Mode Lowlights- Several characters are carry overs from the previous title, making their skills outdated in comparison to story mode progression- Some characters missing from story mode for no reason- Balancing issues, certain characters standard attacks can hit you even if you spam log--Online Mode Highlights- It allows you to play with people onlineOnline Mode Lowlights- Net code is absolutely terrible. Ridiculous input delay makes the game nearly unplayable.- Very low online population. The people who do play are veterans with hundreds of hours - you will get wiped.- Items are not standardized and reflect larger balancing issues. --Overall, I can't recommend buying this game with the next one coming out next month. Unless you REALLY want to play some Naruto goodness right away, hold off for the next iteration which will have three times more characters and some real development on the versus mode side. But don't hold your breath for better online - this is clearly not a priority.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												A simplistic fighting game that takes the more casual gamer approach.The singleplayer campaign is very fun and a vast improvement of the earlier singleplayer games of Ultimate Ninja Storm. There is no need for such things as grinding or a crap load of side quests (there are some but I did them all in over an hour or two). The game is seemingly easy all the way through the single player, tho the two last bosses were really challenging to me (and by two, I mean the secret boss once you finished the singleplayer).  The multiplayer aspect is a fun, casual fighting game style that is very easy to get into and being able to pull of quite a bit. This is the biggest reason you should get the game. I've had plenty of fun moments in the multiplayer even tho at some times it feels like "whoever substitute blocks first wins". But once you played it a bit you should learn how to counter act substitution blocking. Such as timing in a support move or using a jutsu depending on your character.The awakening mode may seem overpowered and sometimes it certainly gives a ridiculous advantage. However this can be remedied by using support characters and keeping a distance. Since a lot of the "powerful" awakening modes makes the characters ridiculously huge.The visuals are pleasing to the eye, the fighting is smooth and the game over all feels polished and done well. I only once got a bug out of the hundreds of fights I've had.Would recommend to anyone who enjoys fighting games, advanced players or rookies alike.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Faithfully tells the story of the anime from after the end of the Pain arc through the Great Ninja War.  The plot part of the game can be nailed in less than ten hours; then the game goes into "free roaming" mode, which is essentially RPG-lite.For fans of the anime who don't mind revisiting the plot (or who stopped watching at the end of Pain arc), it's amusing enough.  The combat is largely satisfying, if nothing too original or ground-breaking.There's at least one boss-fight that is a terrible exception though - where the combat design seems to have taken a jump back 16 years:  Instead of a fun fight, instead you're stuck repeating the same ultimate move again and again and again to chip down an enemy's ridiculously over-large health bar - while your attacks are inexplicably♥♥♥♥♥♥weak for the first time in the game.  The game instantly stops being fun at that point and becomes a massive chore where you've got to memorise attack patterns and slowly grind away like it's a game out of the late 90s.The RPG elements aren't great - it's cool walking around the Hidden Leaf, etc, but the world's pretty small and most of the quests involve wandering around the same areas blindly until you stumble over such-and-such an item.  Some of the quests are unclear about what you're supposed to do - which makes it feel even more aimless.Also refuses to give you quests all at the same time - literally forcing you to retrace your steps for absolutely no reason other than to pad the game's play-time by a tedious extra 10 hours.The gameplay is pretty fun on the whole, and it's cool to revist the anime; but there's questionable depth to it, and the franchise seems to be rendering older entries obsolete with each sequel, making it of questionable value to spend time exploring every odd corner of the game, etc.For people completely new to the anime, this isn't the best place to start.  You'd be better off streaming Naruto anime online; then move on to streaming Naruto Shippuden before moving onwards.  It's not that the plot is hard to follow, or anything, just that there's hundreds and hundreds of episodes of the anime that cover plot before this game is set - and a lot of the backstory simply isn't covered in this game.On the other hand, if you just want a quick silly anime-themed 3D fighter to mess around with - then you might find you like the setting enough to go back and check out the anime instead.Generally, I'd say steer clear of this game unless it's ridiculously cheap and you literally have nothing better to do.  And be ready to drop it as soon as it becomes a drag, as there's a lot of content that is even more boring than the time wasted unlocking it.I'd suggest using a gamepad to play this game (I use a generic gamepad with X360CE and it works flawlessly); as a 3D fighter it uses both thumb-sticks as well as a D-pad simultaneously, so a fight-stick won't be optimal.  I gather that players using the keyboard are enjoying the game fine though, so YMMV.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												For the first Naruto game on PC, Namco and Cyberconnect 2 obviously took the last one. This game has what every Naruto fan would want. Good graphics = Check, Huge Roster = Check, Gigantic Story Mode = Check, Simple but fun battle system = Check. The game let you control Naruto's story after Pain is defeated : The village is under rebuilding, Sasuke is still missing and everything is not rainbows and sunshine in the leaf village. Meanwhile Tobi from Akatsuki sides with Kabuto to capture the last two hosts, Naruto and a certain Killer Bee. After Generations, CC2 did once again a great job with the story mode, putting back epic bosses battles and dramatic long cutscenes. CC2 also did some changes to the battle system, two awakening systems and some addons to the support system. The PC version also gets better graphics, up to 1080p with some AA. The only downside is the lack of optimization and the poor controls ( If you don't own a Xbox360 controller for Windows. ). The game includes almost every DLC costumes of the console version and adds up the Uchiha Vs Sage Kabuto from the Full Burst DLC.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Great battle simulation game for the naruto shippuden television series, kind of a mortal combat sort of thing, if you have watched anything to do with naruto or naruto shippuden, i suggest you get this game. Though if you are not very far into the shippuden series, the story mode in the game could potentially spoil it for you, and online can sometimes be difficult to play with friends and people in far regions, but other than that, the free battle mode is excellent, you can choose your own fights and play over 100 different challenge matches if you want to, even organise tournaments. This is a fantastic game and i highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												This game already simply amazing when it came out. Here's is what's good about this game:◘ Amazing Story but went different from the actual show(Naruto Shippuden) still amazing.◘ Beautiful 3D Graphics, I tip my hat to you CyberConnect 2 from not failing at this from the first game especially.◘ Good cutscenes.◘ So many more playable characters than NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM Generations.◘ Awesome music.◘ Fairly easy to learn the combos and fighting style of each character.◘ Fair ranking system.◘ After the story has ended, you're able to roam free around the shinobi world along with more missions, requests, and survival.◘ Multiplayer is better than previous games.The only thing I can really not like about this game is the community but I'm not surprised and you shouldn't be either if you have played the rest. But you'll find that only sometimes you'll find worthy opponents to beat fairly and actually enjoy the match.I'm still going to give it a 10/10. ☼

Single Player mode also lets you catch up on the story and experience it hands on with massive battles that'll keep you at the edge of your seat(or couch in my case). Can't forget to mention how happy I am to see the series test the waters on the PC platform. This game is a must buy to all Naruto and anime fans alike, and those who love fighting games.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Man this is alot of fun. I been playing through the story mainly which has walk around areas similar to that of the Final Fantasy ones and minor RPG elements. The battles are of course the meat of the game. The cinematics are spectacular and while there is QTEs they don't bother me as much and are never really out of place. IF you are a Naruto fan in any way you will love this game. But even if you arent its still got a very fluid and addictive battle system while being very unique to other fighting games. Personally I missed out on alot of episodes in the latter series but I'm still enjoying the game very much so far. The price is maybe just a tad high but even so it is a VERY polished and well done game. Another thing I'm unsure about is how it controls with keyboard and mouse as I been playing it with a controller. I think either way you will like one this alot!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 throws you into one of Naruto lore's most titanic battles right from the start. Without any preamble you find yourself clashing with the 20-story-tall Nine-Tailed Demon Fox as he ravages Naruto's home village. Except it isn't Naruto's home village, because he hasn't been born yet. Because this is, at last, the series' cataclysmic battle from the past that's been teased for years, but never fully shown before. It's a great first impression, and it sets the pace for the best Ultimate Ninja Storm to date....And you're flung straight into it. First as Naruto's father, who must face off against the masked mastermind controlling the gigantic beast, and then as the Third Hokage in a breathtaking, intense battle that's fought leaping from rooftop to rooftop, circling around this monstrously large terror, coordinating with fellow ninja to hold the creature at bay. This series has pushed its visual spectacle to new heights with every installment, but it’s in moments like this that UNS3 proves to be the most epic and most fanservice-packed.When you’ve finally managed to take down the Demon Fox, there’s no chance to catch your breath – because you’re then flung right back to Naruto's dad, still in the middle of his own fight. UNS3 bounces around like this dynamically. You can be halfway through a major clash, then the focus will shift to another battlefield or point in time and have you fight a second, simultaneous fight before circling you back around to your starting point. It's a brilliant break from tradition that constantly keeps your attention focused and your energy up. It could've gone wrong and been distracting, but since each instance is interwoven with the storyline and serves a plot-advancing purpose, I never felt like I was bounced around for no reason.For the most part, this is the same Ninja Storm combat as before – just a bit faster. Ultimate Ninja Storm 3's feels as if the controls have gotten tighter and more responsive, which was appreciated as I ran, dodged, and teleported my way around each 3D battleground trying to gain a positional advantage over my opponent. Some mechanics introduced in earlier installments have been tweaked, too, like the fact that you can now enter your character's "Awakened" state without waiting until their health bar has been depleted to the edge of death.Things are a bit easier, too. UNS3's difficulty settings seem muted, as few fights will offer a true challenge to anyone who's bested any of the earlier games. The most elite players will have to seek out high-level opponents online, because the AI won't keep up with you.At some points during the story, UNS3 offers some confusing decisions about which of two paths you want to follow. They're presented as a choice between the "Legend" path or the "Hero" path, but aren't both of those good things? I suppose being a "Legend" is more epic than just being a plain old "Hero," but it's odd phrasing – and it's made even more perplexing because you earn either Legend Points or Hero Points for picking one over the other, and the distinction between those is never adequately explained.Experimenting with picking different story paths does open up unique cutscenes and fights not previously seen on the cartoon, though, so the confusion is worth enduring. In the opening clash against the Nine-Tailed Fox, for instance, you get to witness Choza Akimichi grow to Godzilla-like proportions and bodyslam the 20-story beast. So it's worth experimenting with, at least.Other than that, as with the earlier Ultimate Ninja Storm games, this one sticks pretty close to retelling the cartoon's plots point for point. Those decision moments are your opportunity to deviate a bit, which keeps things from being a total retread. You’re ultimately funneled back to the core timeline after having witnessed the extra, side content, so the decisions are never too earth-shattering – you can’t end up picking a path where Naruto dies or anything like that.Some fans will no doubt take issue with the story's ending in this installment, as it's non-canonical and probably not a reflection of what will be seen in the show. Alternate story paths diverging from the events of older episodes are fun "what if?" scenarios worth taking a look at. But when UNS3 starts projecting out past the scope of currently aired TV episodes and currently published manga to invent its own vision of Naruto's future, the waters get a little choppy.One area that disappointed was the limited exploration in story mode – we're teased with free-roaming areas every once in awhile, but they never amount to much and you're quickly shuffling back into watching the next sequence of cutscenes. Also: do we really need all Fuu the Insect Girl as a playable character? We have over 80 now – it's probably safe to stop scraping the bottom of that barrel.Even if the difficulty skews toward the easy side, Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 speeds up combat with more responsive controls, and the visual spectacle of it all is more stunning than ever. Just as importantly, maintaining critical emotional connections to the story, even amidst all the chaos and explosions, overrides my concerns about non-canon story choices and lets us have fun with "what if" scenarios. Ultimate Ninja Storm's reputation as Naruto's most consistently enjoyable game series is safe.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												I am personally not a fighting game fan, so this is more of for the casual gamer.I have so much fun with Naruto titles, it's just a mixture of the lore, I am a fan of Naruto, and the cool gameplay mechanics that make this game amazing. I have not played the campaign other than the first level (avoiding spoilers since I'm still on Part I of the series) but it is a lot of fun. The boss battles have cool elements that make you feel like you're not just smashing away on the B button within a certain window. Cinematic fighting scenes in the battle keep the battles fresh and exciting.Since I don't know much terminology for a fighting game, I'll just end it here. I rate this game a 9/10 and would definitely recommend to any fans of the Naruto series.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												tl;dr I give this game a 6/10. If you are a huge fan of naruto be sure to pick it up, but if you're not you might want to buy something else instead. First let's talk about the story and animation of the game. I really enjoyed the animation sequences and story mode, because it was like watching the anime but in cell-shaded 3D graphics. I have never watched the episodes that this game was based off of, and it made it that much more enjoyable because it caught me up to speed. That being said, the plot was a little too predictable for me and boring at times. The gameplay of this game is OK. It feels kind of like a generic action game, but it has a chakra system and combo system which adds some depth. The kunai throwing does not seem to have any use. The time it takes to throw the kunai is time you could be using to close the gap on the opponent, and the damage the kunai does is so little that it's not even worth it. There are some issues with the combo system though, mainly that there is always going to be one combo that does the most damage and is usable in every situation. To avoid this they should have made multiple top-damage combos that are each used in different situations. The UI and title screen could use some work, and I also had some issues getting the game to run at a proper frame rate. It had nothing to do with my hardware, but with the default settings that the game had. I would say that even though the game is good, the port of the game was very sloppy.I give this game a 6/10. It is an above average game, but does not score higher than a 6 because of its bland combo system and port issues.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												This game is something else, I'm having mixed feelings about the gameplay and multiplayerSingleplayer/Campaign: The Single player is alright, however the AI are easy to defeat, I feel like there is no challange to them, maybe its just me.Campaign has almost the original story behind the anime, except you miss out on most of the battles like Danzo VS Sasuke and a couple of others, it begins after Pain destroyed Konohagakure, leaving the village to repair itself, by then Naruto has set out to the five kage summit, on the way there he meets various amounts of people along with you playing most of themUltimate ninja storm 3 offers a unique combat system when you are not fighting One v One, I call it target switching where you're fighting a group of weak AI, sometimes the game will through "bossess" which do heavy attacks and are tougher. During the combat there will be a quick option to press A if you're using the controller, no Idea what it is for keyboard, pressing A allows you to jump inbetween targets, getting rid of them faster.Multiplayer/AI Multiplayer: The main thing fighting games are made for is multiplayer, the soul key so players can go head to head, in Naruto, I must say some of the characters are a little unbalanced but that is expected because each and over one of them are differently skilled.Some of them can be slow attacking, most of them are usually ranged and occasionally you'll have the close up fighters like Might-Guy, Rock Lee, Killer Bee, and Ay (Raikage).During the multiplayer experience most of the players will more than likely spam jutsu, this is acceptable because most fighting games are like this.There are loads of tactics, timing, and coordination with your partner (which I'll get to soon).There is another mode which allows you to pick 2 or 1 teamate, specifically from the collection of characters.Your teamate has 3 roles he/she can be, Attack, Guard, and BalancedAlthough the character have many ways to describe each role, EXAMPLE: I choose gaara with guard because in the anime he uses his "Great Defense" sand as his defense, or hinata because she has the trigrams thingy which allows her to deflect enemies and projectiles(((AI MULTIPLAYER))):AI multiplayer is playing by yourself with bots, although not recommened because of how boring it can be by yourself, but practice makes perfect :)Training against bots with unlimited health is ideal, there are tons of options in which you can choose to mix up your gameplay.Thats all, so so far I rate this game a 8/10Thanks~ Zambie

												As a Naruto fan, this pleased me in various ways. It's a solid and fun fighting game that you can play locally with friends, or take the brawl online. It looks stunning thanks to the graphical revamp that came with Full Burst. Single Player mode also lets you catch up on the story and experience it hands on with massive battles that'll keep you at the edge of your seat(or couch in my case). Can't forget to mention how happy I am to see the series test the waters on the PC platform. This game is a must buy to all Naruto and anime fans alike, and those who love fighting games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 throws you into one of Naruto lore's most titanic battles right from the start. Without any preamble you find yourself clashing with the 20-story-tall Nine-Tailed Demon Fox as he ravages Naruto's home village. Except it isn't Naruto's home village, because he hasn't been born yet. Because this is, at last, the series' cataclysmic battle from the past that's been teased for years, but never fully shown before. It's a great first impression, and it sets the pace for the best Ultimate Ninja Storm to date....And you're flung straight into it. First as Naruto's father, who must face off against the masked mastermind controlling the gigantic beast, and then as the Third Hokage in a breathtaking, intense battle that's fought leaping from rooftop to rooftop, circling around this monstrously large terror, coordinating with fellow ninja to hold the creature at bay. This series has pushed its visual spectacle to new heights with every installment, but it’s in moments like this that UNS3 proves to be the most epic and most fanservice-packed.When you’ve finally managed to take down the Demon Fox, there’s no chance to catch your breath – because you’re then flung right back to Naruto's dad, still in the middle of his own fight. UNS3 bounces around like this dynamically. You can be halfway through a major clash, then the focus will shift to another battlefield or point in time and have you fight a second, simultaneous fight before circling you back around to your starting point. It's a brilliant break from tradition that constantly keeps your attention focused and your energy up. It could've gone wrong and been distracting, but since each instance is interwoven with the storyline and serves a plot-advancing purpose, I never felt like I was bounced around for no reason.For the most part, this is the same Ninja Storm combat as before – just a bit faster. Ultimate Ninja Storm 3's feels as if the controls have gotten tighter and more responsive, which was appreciated as I ran, dodged, and teleported my way around each 3D battleground trying to gain a positional advantage over my opponent. Some mechanics introduced in earlier installments have been tweaked, too, like the fact that you can now enter your character's "Awakened" state without waiting until their health bar has been depleted to the edge of death.Things are a bit easier, too. UNS3's difficulty settings seem muted, as few fights will offer a true challenge to anyone who's bested any of the earlier games. The most elite players will have to seek out high-level opponents online, because the AI won't keep up with you.At some points during the story, UNS3 offers some confusing decisions about which of two paths you want to follow. They're presented as a choice between the "Legend" path or the "Hero" path, but aren't both of those good things? I suppose being a "Legend" is more epic than just being a plain old "Hero," but it's odd phrasing – and it's made even more perplexing because you earn either Legend Points or Hero Points for picking one over the other, and the distinction between those is never adequately explained.Experimenting with picking different story paths does open up unique cutscenes and fights not previously seen on the cartoon, though, so the confusion is worth enduring. In the opening clash against the Nine-Tailed Fox, for instance, you get to witness Choza Akimichi grow to Godzilla-like proportions and bodyslam the 20-story beast. So it's worth experimenting with, at least.Other than that, as with the earlier Ultimate Ninja Storm games, this one sticks pretty close to retelling the cartoon's plots point for point. Those decision moments are your opportunity to deviate a bit, which keeps things from being a total retread. You’re ultimately funneled back to the core timeline after having witnessed the extra, side content, so the decisions are never too earth-shattering – you can’t end up picking a path where Naruto dies or anything like that.Some fans will no doubt take issue with the story's ending in this installment, as it's non-canonical and probably not a reflection of what will be seen in the show. Alternate story paths diverging from the events of older episodes are fun "what if?" scenarios worth taking a look at. But when UNS3 starts projecting out past the scope of currently aired TV episodes and currently published manga to invent its own vision of Naruto's future, the waters get a little choppy.One area that disappointed was the limited exploration in story mode – we're teased with free-roaming areas every once in awhile, but they never amount to much and you're quickly shuffling back into watching the next sequence of cutscenes. Also: do we really need all Fuu the Insect Girl as a playable character? We have over 80 now – it's probably safe to stop scraping the bottom of that barrel.Even if the difficulty skews toward the easy side, Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 speeds up combat with more responsive controls, and the visual spectacle of it all is more stunning than ever. Just as importantly, maintaining critical emotional connections to the story, even amidst all the chaos and explosions, overrides my concerns about non-canon story choices and lets us have fun with "what if" scenarios. Ultimate Ninja Storm's reputation as Naruto's most consistently enjoyable game series is safe.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												I am personally not a fighting game fan, so this is more of for the casual gamer.I have so much fun with Naruto titles, it's just a mixture of the lore, I am a fan of Naruto, and the cool gameplay mechanics that make this game amazing. I have not played the campaign other than the first level (avoiding spoilers since I'm still on Part I of the series) but it is a lot of fun. The boss battles have cool elements that make you feel like you're not just smashing away on the B button within a certain window. Cinematic fighting scenes in the battle keep the battles fresh and exciting.Since I don't know much terminology for a fighting game, I'll just end it here. I rate this game a 9/10 and would definitely recommend to any fans of the Naruto series.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												It's an odd feeling enjoying a game only until you get good at it. The main fighting part of the game becomes repedetive quite quickly as the AI demands you pull no punches and rely on the same unblockable moves and counters in order to progress. The re-imagined scenes from the anime are spot on and the animations (on the most part) are smooth and responsive while actually playing the game.It's not a perfect game by far but, for me at least, it was well worth it's sale price... I'm afraid I didnt have the time or inclination to try its online vs options so I can't comment on that.7/10

content:
Posted: March 14
												To all of the people who say you can't play with keyboard, yes you can. Well, at least I can. The "Keyboard" config is at the bottom of the controller configuration list on startup.I absolutely love this game, and I love the Ultimate Ninja Storm Series. I bought 2, 3, Revolution, and 4. I honestly wish I had a PS3 to play Ultimate Ninja Storm 1.Having Ultimate Ninja Storm 4, I have to say that there isn't VERY much to the story mode. Sure, they added Adventure, but it really isn't the same. Playing UNS:3 is great, and this is a perfect example of what Revolution could have been(They got rid of a story mode for Ultimate Ninja Tournament. It wasn't a bad mode, just a bad move.) Sure, I guess it had that Mecha Naruto story, but that was literally Ultimate Ninja Tournament with extra battles in the end.So, if you want a PERFECT game of the Ultimate Ninja series, I recommend Ultimate Ninja Storm 3. If you want less than perfect, yet still very enjoyable, get Ultimate Ninja Storm 4. If you want, "What exactly in the f*** were you thinking?", yet okay then get Ultimate Ninja Storm: Revolution.

content:
Posted: February 25
												Espetacular jogo baseado no ótimo anime Naruto Shippuden! Você vai conhecer a história do jogo desde seus primórdios e acompanhar o decorrer do anime desde a vitória de Naruto contra Pain até antes da revelação da face do mascarado "Madara" durante a Terceiro Guerra Ninja (o jogo não mostra quem está por trás, mas vc já sabe, né?)! São quase centenas de personagens destraváveis para jogar, o modo história é muito legal e as batalhas são muito fluídas, com personagens com os mais variados tipos de habilidade e estratégias de combates. Isso com um controle muito simples de se usar. Enfim, excelente jogo de luta e ação, recomendado para todos os fãs da série Naruto Shippuden!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												This game is a extremly nice addiction to the storyline for all fans of masashi kishimoto´s Naruto,especcialy if you are into turnament like fighting games.The graphics of this are ok and every character has a own attackset, there are also multible outfits for most characters.Huge plus u can fight outside the storymode with a good set of characcters (also with up to 2 support characters).If you are used to play with a controler it helps here, because it tooks a few hours to get the controls right on the keyboard,(you have to set the keybindings manually bevore starting to play, but can change it later so experiment a bit).Also try to test the different combos for the characters in the training mode to get a hint of the capabilities and weaknesses of the characters.Positive:+ Good story addition to the known Naruto plot [Epiloge is the Attack of the Kyuubi :3]+ Graphic acceptable, nealry no glitchines and the armature (character skeleton) looks well set.+ Mulitble characters to play with in Singlebattle, Turnament -> also online+ Price is ok, would have bought it for more ^^+ The AI ist to dump and can be trouble (if you enable all moves/attacks/etc. for them).+ Extermly nice Bossfight with Kurama ^^Negative:- Keyboardcontrols needs some time to addjust, will give you a handycap in onlineplay against experienced controller players, but it is possible to finish the games with the best grade.- Onlineplay can be a bit glitchy, thanks to laggs, but it doesnt really reduce the fun ^^- Some translations of the subtitles are not really accurate, so i switches to english and the spoken language to japan.   (nice if you are used to watch the anime with eng subs ^^)Recommendation: Watch the trailers and if you like this kind of games BUY IT!

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I really wasn't expecting much from this game I only have it because a friend gave it to me and I felt obligated to play it, but I'm glad I did because the game is actually a lot of fun.I don't like the anime, so I really don't think I have any kind of bias supporting it at all. This is probably why I am getting sick of the story mode right now since the cut-scenes can drag on for quite a while and I found myself skipping them a lot when I got the general jist of what the scene was about (sometimes even before that) and I would sometimes lose the context of a curtain fight.But this IS a fighting game so the story isn't important what is important is the fighting system and I really like it. It's quite unique from other fighting games I've played and still manages to keep a kind of "easy to learn, hard to master" element. Most of the characters are pretty ballenced, except for the ones that have very fast acting far-ranged moves (like the exploding birds from what-his-face) that make fighting them with another character a real chore when it requires a lot more skill to beat someone who's just spamming the X button all day that is just as strong as special attacks, but doesn't use any energy for some reason. I wish the game had a few more options though, it's basically a boring story mode, or fight other people online. With the amount of resorces the delveopers put into the story mode I feel like they could have toned it down a little to allow room for other features.But I digress, the fighting system was enough fun for me to sink more then 10 hours into the game, I just feel like the game could have used at least one other feature instead of another 3 hours of cut-scenes for the story mode.

												I really wasn't expecting much from this game I only have it because a friend gave it to me and I felt obligated to play it, but I'm glad I did because the game is actually a lot of fun.I don't like the anime, so I really don't think I have any kind of bias supporting it at all. This is probably why I am getting sick of the story mode right now since the cut-scenes can drag on for quite a while and I found myself skipping them a lot when I got the general jist of what the scene was about (sometimes even before that) and I would sometimes lose the context of a curtain fight.But this IS a fighting game so the story isn't important what is important is the fighting system and I really like it. It's quite unique from other fighting games I've played and still manages to keep a kind of "easy to learn, hard to master" element. Most of the characters are pretty ballenced, except for the ones that have very fast acting far-ranged moves (like the exploding birds from what-his-face) that make fighting them with another character a real chore when it requires a lot more skill to beat someone who's just spamming the X button all day that is just as strong as special attacks, but doesn't use any energy for some reason. I wish the game had a few more options though, it's basically a boring story mode, or fight other people online. With the amount of resorces the delveopers put into the story mode I feel like they could have toned it down a little to allow room for other features.But I digress, the fighting system was enough fun for me to sink more then 10 hours into the game, I just feel like the game could have used at least one other feature instead of another 3 hours of cut-scenes for the story mode.

												I'm a huge naruto fan and i must say that even though this is a great game you have to be careful what you do or it'll crash. content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												A Very Nice Anime Game.The Fighting is not too complicate to control and give the Feeling of Awesomeness like the Anime.Totally playable with Keyboard, (Key bind setting in the launcher) But Controllers are recommended. (I play with Keyboard All this time)Hours of Story Mode (~80% watching ~20% playing) Then Exploring the world afterwards, collect the history pages and Fight battles of the past. There are Some QTE in Story mode that rewards Special Cutscenes during the story gameplay.Some of the story battle might feels a bit lacking something (like the Beasts fight)Also There's [Online Play] to test your Ninja skills Online. (Havn't try it much yet)And Free Fight mode where you can fight Locally or fight with A.I. or just Practice.Overall I think This game is worth its cost. Totally.Edit : PS. I've never read or Watch Naruto before playing this game. (of course i've seen it sometimes) But after playing this game I feel like i want to.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												It's an odd feeling enjoying a game only until you get good at it. The main fighting part of the game becomes repedetive quite quickly as the AI demands you pull no punches and rely on the same unblockable moves and counters in order to progress. The re-imagined scenes from the anime are spot on and the animations (on the most part) are smooth and responsive while actually playing the game.It's not a perfect game by far but, for me at least, it was well worth it's sale price... I'm afraid I didnt have the time or inclination to try its online vs options so I can't comment on that.7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												I'm not a fan of Naruto. In fact, I'm generally annoyed by the characters and contrived plot. I am, however, a huge fan of developer CyberConnect2, the creators of the Dot Hack series, Asura's Wrath, and JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: All Star Battle. As far as cel-shading, animation, and action goes, CC2 are the best at it. And this shines even in Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm 3.It took me around 10 hours to complete the single player story. Aside from a little walking around, you get huge battles that are so jaw-droppingly awesome that the only other developers I can think of who'd pull it off is Platinum. If you don't like Naruto like me, that's okay because you can just skip all of the cutscenes. Boss fights are replayable as soon as you complete them, which is a major plus if you love revisiting epic parts of the game without starting from the beginning of the story mode.As far as ports go, this is just the console version slapped on to the PC. Meaning you get no graphics options other than resolution and v-sync. It's not a broken PC port, it's a very solid port that will definitely run as long as your computer meets the specs.

number of helpful: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Firstly: The game is hardlocked at 30 fps. This would be no major issue if you reached the 30 fps mark all the time but unfortunately you don't. The funny thing is, if you got a high- or mid-end system you're most likely going to be stuck at 15-20 fps. This cannot be altered unless you use some 3rd-party tools to stress your gpu, e.g. "Heavyload".My Hardware: CPU ~ i5 4670k @ 3,4 GHzGPU ~ R9 290 @ 4GB VRAM8 GB Ram Secondly: You barely have any gfx options. What you get is: resolution, aspect ratio, vsync, supersampling and that's it.Lastly: The sound options consist of: music volume and speech volume. This would be no major issue either if the sound-fx wouldn't be so ridiculously loud.Conclusion: The Pc-Port of this game is absolutely atrocious. I can't get myself to recommend it in any way. Even if you're a hardcore Naruto fan I'd recommend you to stay away. These are all issues I discovered while "playing" the game for 1 hour. There might be more I didn't discover yet. So be prepared if you decide to buy it nonetheless.Edit: One of the Amd Beta Drivers seemed to resolve the 15-20 fps lock issue. The performance in singleplayer is very poor regardless.And don't expect to play this game on dedicated servers, it's peer-to-peer all the way.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												This port is all-around dreadful. The game is hard locked at 30 fps with slow-down problems when multiple supports are on screen. Online is the most abysmal experience in any fighting game to date due to lag, slow down, and more transition errors you can count even with max strength connections. The only saving grace is the story mode (warning the storm games have their own continuity). The aftermath of the story mode has the most interesting side stories to date in the series. In terms of boss fight quality, I'd say most are above storm 1 but not quite storm 2 quality, the others are of lower quality to storm 1 or around the quality of the kakazu fight. Unfortunatley none of the fights are of pain quality animation from storm 2, but tsunade vs madara does attempt to give pain a run for his money. If you’re getting it to experience a slightly altered timeline from the anime and manga, then go ahead and buy it. If you actually looking for a fighting game than no. The characters are horribly balanced, and the net code for online is worst I’ve seen in a long time. In the end I can’t recommend any storm game past 2 which did everything, with exception of the story after match, just better go play that, or play a good fighting game like naruto storm 1, mk 9, injustice, or street fighter 4. P.S only fights I felt they really messed up on were konan vs madara and naruto, itachi, and bee vs nagato they were really underwelming in comparison to their annime counterparts. Also why the hell was gaara a boss fight if they wern't going to do anything with him.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
 I have played enough of this game, and I think Its time to write review about it.  I recommend this game for all fighting genre lovers!  Lets start with good things: + Amazing Storyline, If you don't want to watch anime, you will understand what happened in hundreds of episodes just by playing this game, Of course some things are changed in Naruto Storm 3 Story compared to the original Anime.+ Great Graphics, If you enable SuperSampling on 2X, The game Is gorgeous.+ A lot of Playable Characters.+ Adventure Mode(In story mode) Is really enjoyable, There are a lots of missions to keep you busy.+ Online mode, You can fight against your friends, or someone who you don't know.+ All dlcs are In this package, Simply you purchase the base game, And you have all dlcs.+ Uchiha brothers story Is Implanted, To unlock It you have to do few tasks which takes time, But In the end, It does worth it. Now the bad things: - Online mode has few problems.- 30fps lock- Adventure mode might get boring for you, Because mostly you go from point A, to point B.- It would be nice to have locked support characters as playable characters.- Cutscenes are long, But It Isn't con for me, For most people It should be.- There are lots of unnecessary loading pauses.- Some of the characters hasn't been updated since Storm 2.- Sometimes camera bugs out.- Sometimes you will notice glitches.Overall I recommend this game for fighting genre lovers, And mostly for Anime: Naruto Shippuden watchers. I rate It 8/10 and recommend buying this on sale, Because last game of Storm franchise arrived already, and If you watch Anime: Naruto Shippuden, You may think storyline Is kinda outdated compared to the current anime storyline.

												Must buy....really solid game.....EDIT: I started playing this game again, (When I wrote the review, I only played about 5% of the story) and I have to say im just completely blown away from the polish, story, music, and last but not last gameplay. This game just might move into my top 10 stories of all time for video games. I have no idea about nartuo, I honestly thought it was a little kids series....but its not. The story in this game is just simply amazing, the voices (I listen in jap) are amazing graphics and effects I would assume are just like the show. Its just so well done. I wish I was a fan of the show I would be going nuts over this game.The QTEs....Ive never seen QTE work so well in a video game....this game makes me want to do more QTE. Its just sooooo epic....the system it uses is perfect as well....the better you do....you unlock a secert part of the cutscene....so even if you suck...you dont have to restart or anything (i think, i never failed the qte so im not sure). They just did it right when it comes to QTE.The story....wow...moved me in ways i dont feel comfortable talking about on steam :PThe story combined with the AAA music just makes your emotions go insane....its really remarkable!Just a great game....I will make sure to purchase all further nartuo titles.....also going to look into the TV series....

												Sorry for my spelling, puncuation, and lack of sentence flow in advance. This is my first  review.Naruto Shippuden UNS3 Full Burst is a outstanding game for both Naruto fans (like myself) and for the avid fighting game fan (like myself). Think Street Fighter with a few more mechanics and a whole hell of a lot of chacters to choose from. To the not Naruto fan. I do highly advise you get this game *on sale*; if you don't care for the cut scenes; you can skip them by hitting start. Just play the game and I promise you, if you are a fan of fighting games (Tekken, Street Fighter, Killer Instinct, SNK vs Capcom,etc) you will adore this game.  For the on the fence Naruto fan, I can not express this enough BUY THIS GAME! *Espically on sale* Not only is the actually gameplay outstanding, the cutscenes and the Secret Events will definatley invoke some good ol Naruto memories *DEH FEELS*. I just finished Kakashi vs Edo Tensei Zabuza , I can remeber sitting on the couch as a youngsteer and watching little tibits of that episode as if it were yesterday. (80% of the Zabuza and Haku arc). ANNNNNNYWAY its a outstanding game that everyone should at least try. If you like fighting games but, if you don't thats cool to. Remeber you can skip the lengthy cutscenes (and trust me there are a few) by hitting the start button.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Note: Don't buy this game at full price. Yeah, I know, I received this product for free but still.. it isn't really worth it considering how long the game has been out imo. [+/-] Overall, This game is alright. If you're a big fan of naruto like me you'll obviously enjoy this game. The main storyline doesn't offer much to be honest, But the battles are incredibly fullfilling which make up for the lack of content this game has. (Even with DLC it's still pretty lackluster). [-] The Combat is very straight forward but rather monotonous. You'll pretty much be mashing the B button the entire time while occasionally pressing the x button to throw a shuriken and Y to rebuild chakra. You're only given about (4)? different types of combos you can do by tilting the stick in different directions but other than that the combat isn't very flavorful. [+] The visual effects in the game are surely a treat. Flashy Ninjutsu, Huge explosions, Climactic Cutscenes, Y'know things to surely get you pumpin' and hyped up during your gameplay. Which is a plus! [+] The roster is quite expansive which is great. This allows for much variety especially when playing online.. IF THE ONLINE PLAY WAS ACTUALLY STABLE THOUGH. [-] Um..Yeah the online play is truly abysmal in the PC version of storm. Which definitely left a bad taste in my mouth since the 'Ultimate Adventure Mode' doesn't offer much. It lowers the amount of replayability greatly. ):<This game gets a 7/10 from me though. - Meh story mode (Awful free roam, little to no Interaction with NPCs, Extremely Linear)- Entertaining battles but with boring mechanics.- A great roster.- Nearly unplayable online mode.Written By: http://steamcommunity.com/id/dereden/

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I picked up this title when it was released on Steam, partially for my significant other, who is a Naruto fan, and partially for myself, as a fan of the games.  For the record, let me start off by saying that I feel the manga is only so-so, and that I hate the anime.  Let that generate whatever feelings you want going into this, because I have always been a fan of the games.Namco Bandai and Cyber Connect 2 teamed up to bring a part of the Naruto Shippuden world in this action/adventure title.  The game sort of feels like playing any one of the Tales games, but has a few unique elements to it that set it apart.  The combat system is very simplified, clearly intended for children to be able to pick up and button mash to be able to make it through the beginning parts of the game and develop the skill of pushing buttons with purpose as they play through it.  This works out for adults too because the game has no real tutorial mode, not for how to fight at any rate, and the moves list is very rudimentary.  Combats are smooth, however, due to this lack of complication.  You can get out of combos with the substitution technique, which many newer arcade fighters could benefit from some way to get out of a stun lock, but the characters get stuck in combos easily once you start them, so the only way to protect yourself in some situations is that technique.  Buttons aren't particularly hard to reach or remember, though it is a little awkward at first.  Notably, I have not tried the keyboard controls for the game at this point, only the xbox360 controller I use on my pc.  Local multiplayer, of course, is a nice feature.  The game appears to support up to 8 controllers, from what I can tell, but I'm not entirely certain on that.  I know for certain that it does four controllers, which is useful for the built in tournament system put in the game.As for the story mode, Bandai delivers, much like they do with the Tales series.  If I did have any complaint on this part of the game, it would be that you don't have enough influence over the events like you do in a true rpg.  You'll be spending up to a half an hour through some cut-scene sequences, but the scenes are beautifully done and give a lot of consolidated insight into the events that take place throughout the animation series in a much more concise manner.  For those of you not wanting to sit through dozens of filler episodes with the characters monologuing or screaming an entire episode as they power up their ultimate attack that will actually go off two or three episodes later, then this is the way you want to experience the Naruto story and world.  For the rest of you, I'm sure you have no trouble tracking down the anime episodes to watch through at your leisure.  The ability to explore the world would be more interesting with more to do in the world, but I won't say that the game is bad by the lack of stuff to do.  It is, at its core, the same thing that the Naruto anime is...a fight show, and it does it far better than the anime does.   While I tend to avoid games from other media like movies and whatnot, this game stands out with masterfully rendered cutscenes that look like they were taken straight out of the animation, but are actually simply redone with the 3D models of the characters in the game.  The voice acting for the English side is the same as the US releases, so the performances are at least consistent.  If you like that, there you go.  For those of you that prefer the Japanese voices, Bandai was awesome enough to leave the original Japanese voice sets in the game, so you can experience it with the higher quality performance of the original voice actors from Japan.  At $40 on steam, the game is pricy, but less expensive than other arcade battlers and comes with a robust cast of characters, costumes, and hours of gameplay.  I highly recommend this title to not only fans of the anime, but people who aren't fans of the the series, but like a good fight game.  It is well done, and offers a lot that many other games could learn from.Update:  I just tried playing the game online for the first time and had severe problems with being disconnected over and over again.  This is something that will need to be fixed, as the game is just about unplayable online right now.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												first of all i watched naruto anime until now and i have all the previous Naruto games on ps2 and ps3 so i am a big naruto video game fan but that doesnt mean i am gonna give it 10/10 because of that and i am reviewing this so i could get a steam achievment :)Story:Since i wath the anime i skiped all of the cinematics they are not as interesting as in anime,subtitles are made for english language not japanesse  so the words are much simplier and the writing is a little dull like its made for a lot younger audience but anyway it explains the story well.There are a lot cinematics,a lot more than in  previous naruto storm games,you dont have to watch the anime to play this but youl have to play previous storm games because you are gonna be confused.Story wise the story is stupid but its not bandai namcos fault its the manga writer fault and i am not taking this in the account since the manga cant be changed.Graphics:This is not so good pc port,it only has options for resolution and anti anialising(supersampling in this case),so yeah not very good and its 30fps like on consoles.But it  runs solidly,i didnt encounter any bugs or so.Graphics are pretty,animation is amazing,now it character move more fluently than any naruto game before, and are much better than on consoles,but only if you max it out  the difference is big though, but of course its gonna look better becase it has 1080p support.GameplayThis is not the best naruto game thought in terms of improvments and new stuff The gameplay is completely the same as naruto ultimate ninja storm generations.Although it has little improvment over storm 2 and generation but this is the first naruto game on pc so not gonna count that much.The game has amazing quick time events with beautifull animation so those fights look much better than in anime obviously.Those quick time events happen in some major boss fight and are the main reason for me that i play the story,without them i would be little boring.There are side missons after the story and they add many hours to the game(but they are repetitive and not so interesting),there are also mods like survival which you have to unlock it through story,there is a tournament,free battle obviously and a 100 missions for which you get 10 wallpapers.There are over 70 characters or someting,and that is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.Battles are interesting cause you can choose your main character with one or two support characters.You have 4 combos,ninjutsu,ultimate jutsu and awakenings(on some charaters you can awakened them at any time).I wont into details cause you have to wathc the gameplay. Online gameplay:If you are now buying these to play online and if you have xbox 360 or ps3 then you should choose the console version.The reason for that is cause  there are like 20 ♥♥♥♥ING PLAYERS NOW,i even remeber all of their ♥♥♥♥ing names,on consoles there are much more and much more variaton between players.Also you better have a good internet for this cause it will lag as ♥♥♥♥.If it works well and if there are players it is interesting.There are 1000 ninja info cars which are used to display your online profile and there are titles cause you cant write on info cards for yourself so you have to use the maid titles in the game sound:japanesse is better than english language at least in my opinion and i am sure many people think like thisVerdict:i reccomend this game,its a great game,story last if you wath the cinematics about 10 hours but if you dont,you can finish it in about 7 hours,with missons it last 17 hours,it ads  lot of hours and there are mods like survival which you have to unlock it,and there is also a tourneament and a 100 missions for a  wallpaper, so the game lasts 30+ hours if you want to complete 100%,my final grade would be 8/10 which is a great,if this wasnt a first storm game i would give it probably a 7/10 :D

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Been playing this game for a while and haven't even been bothered playing the story mode as much, mainly because I owned it on the PS3 (not Full Burst though, just the original one). Since I owned it on the PS3 I just been playing Versus on there and instead of bothering doing the extra boss fight on the PC version. But once I got rid of my PS3 version one, I started playing on the PC version..You're playing as Naruto (duh..), as you play through NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst story mode, you'll come across epic boss fights with quick time event which makes it even better. As well with the music placed within the background during the fight.NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst, story mode has many cut scenes and barely any fights. Like you could walk between 1-2 area and then a cut scene will activate if you're still doing the story mode and have not beaten it yet. But it'll be worth it because you'll get to know more about Naruto Shippuden (If you have not seen the anime on where the game is base off.) As well, get ready to get to have urges to cry! Naruto Shippuden story mode has quite of bits of moment that gets you to have urges to cry. Including the extra final boss fight, where Sasuke and Itachi face of against Sage Kabuto who claims to be a god. But he is kinda of unbeatable so during the match is basically just stalling Kabuto for Itachi could just cast a visual jutsu which keeps on looping the battle in Kabuto's eyes over and over endlessly. Overall about the story, everything else in NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst is amazing, the Art, Combat and Story Mode.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												A warning to anyone thinking of buying this game: This game requires an Xbox controller to play. Valve once again fail to mention that this is a shoddy console port from Namco Bandai, like all of their other PC games seem to be, and is practically unplayable without a controlller.Edit: Also, I forgot to mention that this game has the annoying feature of needing you to walk around between fights. I'd prefer just Mortal Kombat style, but it forces you to walk around places with bad camera angles.Not only that, but you don't regain health for each new fight. So if you run out of health items, you get stuck getting one-shotted at the next fight.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												The best anime fighter i've had the pleasure to play the productions values are incredible the game looke incredible the story mode starts from just after the pain fight and ends further then the anime (though i believe a few of the endings of the battles are changed. couple of things to note; Controller is essential but that should be obvious given that it's a fighting game. second: The game is locked at 30fps again for neccessity to keep the flashy ultimate jutsu's and everything looking smooth. Third: The graphics settings are fairly mediocre though it does scale nicely depending on your rig you have no control of the settings apart from the resolution and if you want AA 2X or off. All that being said this is a fantastic port it runs beautifully on Windows 7 and 8.1 and i look forward to putting many more hours in :)

Graphics is nice, however PC ports has one of the BEST graphics settings ever:30fps lock, V sync ON/OFF, AA 2x/OFF, Windowed/full screen. That's it.Don't even try to play without v-sync, It's unplayable. torn frames everywhere.Framerate is♥♥♥♥♥♥on any PC probably. Tried it on my laptop 26-30 fps (with v-sync), tried it on desktop PC, same♥♥♥♥♥♥Final chapter /final boss is lazy developed, cheap fight and too long. Kudos to any masochist who picked LEGEND path on 1st fight in last chapter (in the woods). I got so frustrated i changed it to hero parth (played whole game on legend btw). Whole final chapter is ragefestival. Screenblocking by your assist, bad camera angle, lock on 1 enemy when you fight 2... lagged controls. What♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off apart from 1v2 7-tails fight (had to mention it it's cheap as ♥♥♥♥). ♥♥♥♥ING FLASHBACK during a COMBO because it is so STUPIDLY coded, that it ignores the fact that you are in the middle of an full combo input, suddenly 1 minute long boring flashback on pointless quotes from past enemies. Tsunade in chapter 8 was more fun than this♥♥♥♥♥♥Oh and one last rant. Fight against Mizukage as Gaara - he rekt me by infinite spam. he stood on furthest spot possible and shot water bullets towards me. And again, and again and again. I got K.O twice, dropped chakra bubbles, lost all chakra, could not even chakra dash od side jump it, and got killed.5/10 Only part I had actual fun was Sasuke on the Summit. At least it's pretty short if you skip everything though.Oh and BONUS Full Burst DLC chapter with sasuke... you have to do ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mission with collecting diamonds THEN you have to travel for good 10 minutes to be able to play it.
