content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												The graphical fidelity and the overall efficiency of this game on PCs is amazing. This is a very well made port of an already super-polished video game. Game's design is modeled after the anime, and at most point it looks infinitely better than the anime. It looks downright beautiful. However, compliments have to end here.The story mode, in my opinion, is too close to the anime. Cutscenes between playable segments, although beautifully animated, sometimes even last longer than your average episode of the anime. If you don't have any prior information about Naruto lore, this game will not be able to ease you in, and in fact will bore and confuse you further. The playable modes in the story mode switch between open-world mode, fighting mode and QTE segments in more climactic fights. The open world mode is incredibly shallow, not much to do other than finding obviously placed loot and talking to NPCS; not sure why they even bothered making it. After finishing the story mode, the entire map is open to explore, but all the newly opened quests feel like a huge time sink. The huge chunk of the playable segments is fighting and it is done alright. There is a branching path system that doesn't really do all that much but it's good that it is there. All fights do try to introduce little quirks to them, which is nice because all characters feel pretty much the same when it comes to control them, thus it would be very boring to go from fight to fight if it wasn't for little differences every once in a while. The QTE segments aren't too long or annoying, but they're problematic as in every other game. The animated segments are done brilliantly but as you are only focused on button prompts, the player doesn't get much chance to really enjoy them. The story mode takes around 10-12 hours to complete but if you skip all the cutscenes I envision it taking you not more than 3-4 hours. There are sometimes hours of playtime between save points so beware. Overall, don't play the story mode unless you have an entire day to waste.The other two modes are Offline and Online battles. Every character plays the same, and only differentiating factor between them is how they use their super moves. Every character gets only two super moves and one "Awakening" mode (which might bestow the character one or two more highly damaging moves). These facts all do in fact hinder the borderline immense character selection.If you have no interest in Naruto, don't get it. If you have, you're better off with waiting for a sale. It does not offer either a liberating open world experience like the Naruto games on XBOX360, nor it does offer a highly sophisticated fighting game experience. However, the game is gorgeous and stays true to the original material.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												6/10Obviously a game for Naruto fans and Naruto fans alone. It's quite clearly a 'movie' license type game, which should instantly let you know what to expect: not a great deal of depth or care and in general a rushed game that has the paint job but not all the soul. Does that make it a bad game? Not at all, but definitely not worth full price. I was lucky enough to pick it up on a 50% off deal, which I still felt was expensive for its end result, but probably fair in the grand scheme of things. Definitely do not pick up at full price unless you're a die-hard fan that wants to feel slightly more connected to the style of fighting and theme.Does the game feel like you're playing the series?To a point, the fights are generally supremely easy (with and without controller (though controller is highly recommended)) and the AI never serves up anything too challenging. The fights that have certain conditions or handicaps are more challenging and fun, but they're few and far between. Multiplayer is naturally more challenging but it is peer-to-peer, so it's not as precise or as rewarding as server-based dueling. And if you pick up the game at this late stage you can expect to be ganked thoroughly throughout. Is the plot any good?Well, it's effectively the abridged version of the anime series. So it cuts and chops pieces with vigor or adds in random fights/conclusions where they don't belong. On top of that it's not really a good tribute to the anime series either, as it gives no or very little attempt to re-create scenes and scenarios in their accurate setting. This means that you'll often have long (and I mean long) cutscenes in a barren environment when, by comparison, in the anime, it's in a city or special setting that accentuates the emotion. There is also zero lip-synching, which always serves as a giant distraction. As a port, is it infuriating?Keyboard user? Yes. Gameplay methodology and movement? Yes. It's strictly for conoles this game, and the PC port was to drive profit from a select group of Naruto fans. Can you still suceed with a keyboard though? Yes, the fights are never too difficult and with enough time keyboard is just as good as the controller; but if you try multiplayer you're looking at a very strict handicap. I love Naruto, but I'm unsure about buying the game; what would you say?I was in the same position, and whilst I had a bit of fun with the game; it didn't live up to expectation. As stated earlier: it is, effectively, a movie-title game; which inherently means the paint job is there but the care and soul isn't. If you've got money to spend then sure you might as well buy it and have some fun with it... But if you're on a budget or would rather save the money, then I would not recommend it to you. It's not a full Naruto experience and game design is on the slim side with elements that exist for little to no reason. I wouldn't say it's a game for the median age of most Naruto watchers (16-25), but rather a game for casuals or under 16s that don't really know any better. Conclusion:If you're on a console, then yes I would say get this game. It's meant to be played with friends and fans of the series rather than independantly or online. The game holds more value in that lens. But on the pc, a naturally solo experience, it falls flat thanks to slim game design, pitifully easy AI, and a general lack of care and soul.

Posted: February 18
												Disclaimer:I won't bother much with graphics, sound or gameplay for this review.I first played Naruto Shippuden UNS3FB on PS3 years back and as a fan that has watched the whole anime brand, as well as read the whole manga (more than once) I liked the game. Graphics were nice and close enough to the anime to get the same immersion... But let's skip my remembering the PS3 Version, since this review regards the cluster♥♥♥♥ of an abomination which calls itself a PC game. to keep it short and simple:On the 4 machines I tried to run this abomination, none worked. Well it did kinda work. But if I got 30 FPS for a few seconds I was a very happy man. The game tended to stay between 5 and 15 FPS. That's about it. Tried it on every new machine I had available and none worked. Don't know how many PC I need to try to get this thing running. I will try again and again, because: I paid for it and sadly didn't know about refund back then. My only recommondation is this: If you have a PS3 and generally like the genre, get it. It's fun to play for a while.If you have a PC: Try to get info if your hardware runs this piece of ... something - if you won't get any, assume it won't run properly. And I am rather sure, that my rig is quite somewhat above the hardware requirements.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												Great game in some aspects, not so much in many others. For starters if you don't have quiet the beastly computer don't even bother trying to play. I'm talking like you can play the 2013 tomb raider at the completely maxed settings kind of beastly. If you do then I hope your a dedicated fan cause your going to be dealing with a lot of typical anime to game issues. For starters you will be forced to run through an "open world" that is really just a bunch of small areas that you run through with linked load screen after load screen, until you finally get to a cutscene. When you finally do get to combat its either a normal fight like if you fought your friends, or one of the main story fights with reaction commands and amazing graphics. Why every story fight isn't like that at this point I don't know. Realistically I have been hoping to see the cinematic reactions appear in the versus modes for this game. Anyway so with a story that should have been like the first budokai (cutscene, fight, cutscene, repeat) this game took a different approach and tryed to let you "free roam" the world of naruto. Also about halfway through the game it introduces a rather annoying system where you will have to fight multiple enemies in the free roam even though your combat is basically no different than it normally is, with the exception of a bunch of moves locked out, and some replaced with almost cheezy reaction attacks. At the end that can become completely ridiculous forcing you to fight multiple bosses by yourself with no real advantage on your side as these coms beat away at you with boss level hp, infinite teleportation abilities, and complicated stacked ai programming that lets them combine their individual attacks into confusing patterns that you'll find yourself beating your head against the wall trying to never figure out. By the time you get to the last boss you feel tired of the whole system almost, and then your in for the most grueling back to back to back to back to back fight that you'll die and have to start aaaaaaaaaallllllllllllllll the way from the beginning of those encounters over, and over, and over. In the end you settle for cheap surfire tactics, struggle through the story to get all the characters, and enjoy replaying the few high res fights with reaction cinematics that the game has. Some of which you will have to do those really annoying parts to be able to play again. So in the end I have to say if your a super dedicated fan with a powerhouse gaming computer then struggle through and enjoy what you have but overall this game was a huge letdown with slightly polished graphics to the original and no change to the overall gameplay dinamic to make it more friendly to players and fun overall. Oh another thing... god this is getting long, the online is massivly problamatic, I've never gotten a game to work, and I have a 1.5 mbps connection, which should be more than sufficient.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Boring and too easy after you figure out "how the ai works" and with the fact that the Online Multiplayer isnt/doesnt work.  It becomes a "not worth it" type of title. (DETAILS WHY)this game is essentially an easier version of DBZ Budikai.  if you dont know what i mean by that let me explain.  (using an xbox360 controller) B is your primary attack....A is to jump....Y is to charge your chakra....and X is to throw stuff.   On top of that you have 2 buttons that pretty much "break" the game.   The block and Substitution buttons.   Block blocks...no big deal and you can hold it all day long...it blocks EVERY attack in front of you.   Substitution however is even worse.   if they do get you in a combo that is chained and you cant get out of....you can use this button to "combo break" them and avoid it completely .... which can be used to counter "ultra" them as well.    in which case if used against the computer...will most always beat them.    This means that you can sit back...charge your ultra bar up to the max... blokc and avoid any kunai thrown at you...substitute out of their combos,,,,and then ULTRA MOVE them ..... repeatedly.  This worked so well as a strat that the game immediatly got boring.....really....really fast.Part 2:  The translations are horrible.  The voice acting is worse (and far different save for naruto) than the english dub.....and there are WAY too many cut scenes for "a fighting game" to even bother with.  I love the anime, I love fighting games like DBZ Budikai..... but when they try to simplifiy it even further than that..screw up something as simple as the story..make you sit through HOURS of cut scenes before the next fight....AND carry over your health bar to EACH fight (of which you just buy and eat ramen between to replenish it) .....as well as "try" to throw in an RPG element.  You just get too many things the game trys to be. What i wish it was:   A fighting game.  If its a fighting game...KEEP IT A FIGHTING GAME.     If you want to make it an RPG where you can collect people to your party and turn base fight.  DO THAT.... dont mix the two and try to hide it behind a fighitng system thats "barely" better than FF13-3 lightning returns. I dont quit many games,   But when i do....i try to warn others about it as much as possible.   This is one of them.

number of helpful: 8 of 20 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												This game has an amazing story following the manga, however I need to stress that this game is NOT for everyone. This game in Story mode is 99% cutscene and 1% battle. If spamming the skip key and long cut scene isn't for you, this game isn't your cup of tea. The free battle mode is what makes this game awesome, with alot of playstyles and combos you can do it sure is what made me appreciate this game and if your a naruto fan, all of your favorite characters are in this game too! However in it's current state, online battle is really laggy and honestly unplayable from where I'm from.(Singapore)But then again the story mode's boss battles are really buggy as the camera angles are REALLY bad. The keyboard configuration took me an hour to set up and it took even longer to find the right keys to bind, so make sure to get a gamepad/controller for the game to function smoothly. If you're getting this game without a gamepad/controller, it isn't worth the full $50 you would need time to adjust to the controls. Overall I would not reccomend this game unless you're a real diehard naruto fan that loves the naruto storyline as the game would not appeal to non fans as it does not explain the full naruto universe and it only includes a part of it. With the game requiring a controller to function well and will certainly not appeal to the vast majority of players.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												First, this game is for Naruto fans only.  Do not buy if you don't get a rock hard boner from hearing anything about Naruto. Now my review.  Wow.  This game is hot garbage.  The one on one battles aren't too bad at times.  A bit repetitious but you get used to the mechanics eventually.  The story is a bit boring as you just run the gauntlet of point A to point B (when the game allows it) then a battle.  99% of the game(?) has turned into me pressing start and skipping.  I really wanted to finish the game but once I got to the end, it's just a huge clusterf***.  What should have been a good idea was quickly filled with rage quit inducing moment.  Breaking the rules of the game so the antagonists get special treatment and powerups is fine if it calls for it, but when you're fighting multiple enemies and your in game camera starts shooting all over the place like Michael J. Fox shooting the Blair Witch combined with Cloverfield and you have no clue where you're at.  The in-battle cutscenes are super-f***ing annoying, where I skipped almost every other cutscene in the game, this makes me sit through 10 minutes of still framed shots with voice over.  Not too mention some a$$hat's bright idea it was to keep your health down when you progress in the story.  Immersive, right?  No, because the only way to reheal it is too go to the one ramen restaurant in the game to heal.  You can't access the health packs in your inventory, no that's stupid.  Not too mention in the final fights when you're fighting 10 story tall monsters, which should be the fun climactic battle of the game, sh*ts it's pants like a 4 year old eating Mexican food.  The developers hid fine little details on how to fight in the battles, which is interesting and can prove to be a fun mechanic, but quickly turns into that time your uncle wanted to play "wrestling".  Plus the item system is basically throwing a single tomato into a salad.  Yeah, it's there but it feels like it doesn't belong and there should be more with it.  I'm thinking way too much into this. Your time would be better spent to just go on youtube and watch someone else play it cause this is not worth the time.  I guess I'll just uninstall it and let it gather electronic dust in my Steam library.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												For this review i would like to point out right away that i won't be rating this game on story since i'm really not a big fan of their writing in general and find the overal series just too over lived. So instead for the story rating , ill just rate this game adventuremode presentation.well off with the review shall we             The whole reason i got this game is because of the fighting. I was curious on how the game worked and to my surprise it really simple, but not in a bad way. How simple you say? 1 button melee and 1 button projectile.  to do specials you have to tap the chakira button once or twice depending on what level of skill you want to use, though each character has only 2 skills  along with very own awakening skills. every character has a unique effect while in awakening state. If your in team fight you can use the top buttons  to throw an asist attack at your enemy. The D-pad eneble you to use utility item fixed to that character. One more thing, chakara can used to charge your other buttons like  jumping to attack cancel to dash toward enemy ot backup or for your projectile attacks. mainly in every fight your goal is to weardown the enemy by making them give out to using their replacement counter. When you get attacked the shoulder bottton can let you sway from the attack and pop you behind the enemy to avoid getting hit from counter either one tme your attack bottons so that you don't keep mashing the attack while the enemy is just laughing at your back. The retaliation aganst a replacement counter is the chakara+jump for dash cancel into the enemy stagger hiim before he makes his counter debut so you can compleat the combo. each player start with four and in an amount of time they will regenerate but each time you use replacement, you temperarly stop the regeneration.the game easy to pick up and play just from looking at the not so complicated move set since every character has an identical button press. They control well but often at times of combat trying to keep a combo or chain just feel odd and fixed. some knock up skill cant be chained with your combo even when it's evident that you are in range of an attack.The system works for what it is but people who like the creat their own combo and discover intricate combos and tricks won't particularly like this mechanic though.            Alright off to the ultimate adventure section. You wana know how good the story mode is. mostly piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Theres a segments where your running around talking to people and finding challenges BUT most of the challenges and sub quest are up after the adventure mode is finished and most of the area you visit feels empty with noone to talk to or interact with except for random item loot on the floor. Though some of the epic fights actaully change the mechanic to make some fight feel dynamic which can be kinda cool. But for something like the final fight being so under powering other then naruto's  shuringan spam. and the 9 tails. The final fight don't feel too epic at all. The adventure mode is to be desired.                 Compleating quest fights or doing hard made give you money and what do you buy with money? Heath potion and over price utility items like explotive shuriken. They never seem nessesary so i pass all the level with flying colors without them, so really the only thing you use money for is unlockables.  This is where im going to talk about content.Unlockable are laughably easy to 100%  since you almost unlock all extra content right from the first play through. Characters however are unlocked just from being in a fight scene in adventure mode. Theres no secret character just all layed out for us. as soony uo beat adventure mode, you have all the characters. Great.......no secrets, but having all 80 characters man thats allot for fighting game, but here really got quantity over quality since some of the character really lack identity or feel unique. But as all content goes atleast the music is able to keep up. The music scores are still strong in the series so yea.  thank you for that.THe thing that i can say for the game is it's graphical envirment and character models are really nicely mode. keep true to the 2 counterpart.             all in all this game is game isn't super terrible just some lost of potential. It's still fun playing the game , but in the long run it's to be desired since the game will run dry in like a half a week. this game get's a 2(1/2) stars out of 5. Never get this at full price.

												Even though walking through the campaign map is as boring as it ever was, the combat system is more smooth than previous entries. There are more fighting and less quick time events, which make it a more challenging game. The graphics are amazing, not in a technical aspect, but because the design nails the design of the manga/anime. It really looks like you're playing the manga. Someone would probably criticize the vast amount of cut scenes, but I don't mind. You really get into the story that way.

												Unplayable on certain GPU's. Worked fine on my Radeon HD 6950 1GB, but with my much newer, much better Radeon R9 290 4GB, it is almost completely unplayable. From what I've gathered online, the game is so badly optimized, it's not compatible with clock speeds that are too high. There are work arounds, but they can wear down, or even damage your GPU, and shorten its lifespan. I wouldn't hold out hope for a patch either. If you want to get it, try looking around the web if your GPU is compatible.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I almost rated this a game as "Not Recommended." That's because some questionable design decisions marred the experience. However, at the end of the day the actual game part of the game is interesting enough to warrant a purchase, especially if you're a fan of Naruto.  So, I'll start with what's bad.  Basically, any part of the single player that isn't fighting (with the exception of the final boss battle. ) Full disclosure: I've been reading Naruto for over 10 years, but I stopped watching the anime at episode 60. It was at that point that I noticed the anime's tendency to draw things out unnecessarily. A manga can be read in a couple minutes, and the anime has the habit of stretching that couple of minutes to half an hour. It makes the experience feel bloated, and that unfortunately is how the single player feels as well.   Through at least 80% of the single player you are, essentially, watching the anime. Yes, it plays out with the game's models, and has a fidelity that arguably surpasses the anime, but it still takes too long to get to anything interesting. The second problem this game has is when the game gives you control outside of fighting. Too often, you are put in a small area, go forward a couple of steps, and a cut scene starts. Even Hideo Kojima would call this♥♥♥♥♥♥excessive. Any part where you were "exploring" was entirely uncessary and could have been removed from the game. Thirdly, the final boss fight is a poorly designed piece of schlock that prioritizes spectacle over playability. Without spoiling too much, the final fight happens over a large area where you can barely see your character and are fighting multiple enemies at once. The fight is grandiose, and fun to look at, but it's still not worth the frustration. You'll get through it, realizing that this was so poorly designed the designers put in multiple checkpoints during the fight, and allow you to refill your health completely and try again if you die. Nowhere else in the game does this happen. It's if they are admitting "we made this to look cool, and for no other reason."Finally, and here's the real kicker. You HAVE to play through this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to unlock characters. If Capcom can figure out that forcing players to unlock characters in fighting games is stupid. Other studios don't have any excuse.Ultimately (heh) what makes this game good is its fighting mechanics. They do a good job interpretting the fiction and are basically a continuation of the mechanics introduced in the arguably superior Ultimate Ninja. However the twist is that this takes place on a 3D plane and looks way way better. The fighting isn't mechanically complex, but it is strategically satisfying. Fighting games are based entirely around the idea of "what I can do vs what the opponent can do." and playing a technical fighting game at a higher level involves a lot of mind games.  This game allows casual players, who don't have the time or the wherewithal to learn 1 frame links and juggles, a chance to play in this manner. You will be thinking "is it better to use substitution, or to block" , "should I attack or throw" , "should I use a jutsu" , etc. It is this fact alone that saves the game. It makes multiplayer* battles so much fun.If this game is between 0 - 15 dollars, it's worth the purchase for an average gamer who wants a fighting game that doesn't require a significant time investment. If it's 15 - 30 dollars it's worth the purchase for a fan of Naruto who is a fan of fighting games.* I have  not tried the online multiplayer, my connection is generally too poor for online fighting games. However, I did test it with a local 2nd player, and was surprised at how this improved my opinion of the game.

												If you're a fan of Naruto and in the mood for some over the top craziness, this is the game for you. While not very challenging at all, the game does keep you engadged with some really cool reinterpretations straight from the anime/manga, accompanied by cutscenes and quicktime events. That being said though, the local multiplayer is tons of fun, and where you can really experiment and mess around with the combat system.This is a great game for any naruto fan that wants to go back through the story, though with a little bit more interactivity, or for anyone looking for a great local multiplayer fighting game.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Okay I luckily got this game on a 50% discount, and it would have been an amazing deal if it weren't for a few issues. Namely there are game breaking bugs that prevent not only the completion of the game, but also causes the game to crash by simply having a character complete a move. This game would have been great if it wasn't for that. Literally my only other complaint is that the settings doesn't have an effects volume part. The story mode is fun and interesting but still follows the manga/anime plot (luckily i've read it so I know what happens after the bug) and the combat is pretty good too. Unfortunately for me, my favorite character is almost unplayable, since his ultimate attack crashes the game if it hits. Certain forms of Naruto might also crash the game, and you cannot complete the story mode because (towards the very end of the battle I might add) the Five Kage battle against Madara causes the game to crash at the exact same unavoidable point in the fight. Therefore I cannot legitamately unlock every character, at least not without grinding money in practice games. Only play this if you are devoted to the franchise, and even then be warned that your favorite characters might just be unplayable. I just wish I could get my 20 bucks back. I realize this is simply a bad port to PC, and that the actual game is extremely fun, but it is very dissapointing that these bugs would be allowed to exist, regardless of circumstance. Its the same as if the Hadouken crashed Street Fighter, or every time you do a Fatality with Scorpion in Mortal Kombat the system shuts off. Now this doesn't happen for everyone, but apparently its a common bug for this game, as looking specifically for this bug to fix it yielded many results and none that fixed it. It is still fun, and as long as I don't use those characters it works fine, but I am severely disappointed that, regardless of the franchise or the love I have for it, something as severe as these bugs and issues would exist, and go unfixed for so long.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												I can't really recommend this game.  First of all, it's a terrible port - they put zero effort into making this work on PC.  There aren't even default keyboard controls.  You can set keyboard controls (only before the game launches, though - you can't set keyboard controls in-game), but as with most fighting games, you're better off just getting a controller (which IS mapped by default).  The default controls themselves are awful - what I expected to be the block button was actually attack, what I expected to be attack was actually throwing a kunai, etc.  It was a little easier and actually playable once I remapped them, but still, I have to knock the game for having a default control scheme that makes absolutely no sense.Second, the game has no practice mode, nor any basic tutorial.  It puts you right into a fight without telling you ANYTHING about how to play the game.  I took a few hits in the first fight before I even figured out how to move (for me, it was actually the D-Pad for movement, not the left thumbstick like the game says).  If you've played one of these before and are already comfortable with their control scheme, this probably won't bother you as you'll already know what does what.  If this is your first Ultimate Ninja Storm game, though, you will be basically be moving and fighting like a toddler while your opponents smack you around effortlessly until you can figure out what's going on.Third, the tutorials you DO get are confusing.  They'll tell you about all these hidden things you can unlock if you do certain things, but they rarely tells you how to do the certain things you need to do to unlock the hidden stuff.  As a result, you'll usually miss the hidden stuff.  Feedback is equally confusing.  It'll say you need to win a fight with at least 40% health as a bonus condition, but the post-fight scoreboard never makes it clear if you've actually done that.Fourth, the story mode makes you win fights that the character you're playing as is supposed to LOSE.  I personally hate that, because it doesn't fit with the story and makes no sense.  I also don't particularly care for the game inventing fights that never took place, but I understand that they need to drag out the gameplay to a certain number of hours.  I would prefer that they stuck to the story religiously in the story mode and then did all these extra fights in a separate 'What if?' mode.Fifth, the story mode saves your characters' health from their previous fights going into the next one.  Sometimes this makes sense, but it usually doesn't.  The game makes you use a health item to restore your character's health so that you have a fair fight.  I don't like having to pay extra just to be at my best for a fight.  That's lame.Sixth, the game doesn't have all of the English voice actors and they didn't even bother to sync up the English lines to the characters' mouths.  Cutscenes look like old Japanese B movies where you hear a character speaking, and then, entire SECONDS after he's done, his character's mouth starts moving.  I could play along with that for real actors or even a cartoon, because to fix it would require a lot of work.  These are CGI models, though.  You can easily make them do whatever you want, so NOT lipsynching the dialogue in the English version is pure laziness.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												PROS: Absolutely spectacular. Cannot recommend highly enough. There's a wealth of depth in the combat system if you care to learn it, but you can also get remarkably far and do remarkably cool things just mashing buttons haphazardly. The story mode is fleshed out superbly with an absolutely staggering amount of voicework from the original Japanese actors (warning, you have to turn Japanese on -- it defaults to the horrendous English actors). So far, I haven't tried VS. mode, but I've unlocked what appear to be an absolute plethora of characters to play. There's also an Online VS. mode which is cool.CONS: The only thing I really dislike about the game is the parts where you're walking around through the village, or through forests, or deserts in an RPG style fashion. The maps are positively gorgeous, and there are hidden treasures to find, but the sluggish speed at which the characters run in these areas really feels awkward with the lightning fast gameplay of the battles and what we've come to know from the show/manga. In battle, Naruto and friends bolt around at amazing speeds we'd expect from ninja -- in the RPG traveling parts, they like... JOG LAZILY. It's really off-putting, and I know it's a weird complaint because the meat of the game is really the fighting, but if I had to pick one complaint about the game, it'd be this.EDIT: A month later, I have to add another con about the game. I am above average at fighting games. I personally found the game's campaign difficult, but never infuriating to the point where I wanted to stop playing. Some fights felt a little cheesy, but never truly unfair. And when there was a DECISION battle, I always took the Legendary (more difficult) route. Toward the very end of the game, there is a Legendary DECISION that, as far as I can tell, is pretty much impossible to beat. There are four-to-five Jinchuuriki ninja beating on you simultaneously. And it'd be one thing if you could perform combos on one of them, but the OTHERS hit and interrupt you -- while you're in the middle of a combo. Just a really stupid fight. I'll admit I'm probably not good enough at the game to beat this particular fight on Legendary, but I never had a real issue with any of the Legendary challenges until this one -- and the gap in difficulty is just absolutely absurd.The game is currently 40% off. I'll admit I had trouble swallowing the $40 price tag, but I've wanted it since it released 6 months ago and I patiently waited until it was on sale. I have to say, if I'd known the game was this good, I would have had NO problem paying full price.Disclaimer: I have to admit, I am a very avid fan of the show and the manga. The game is probably a heck of a lot less exciting if you have never watched it, but I can tell you with confidence that it is still an exceptionally deep and mechanically sound game with gorgeous graphics and the BEST story mode I have ever played in a fighting game.OVERALL: 8/10.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												First of all, this review comes from a fan of the series and a fan of PCs, so imagine how happy I'm to be able to play this on my computer.I'll just point out some CONs on the Port (and not the game) I found while playing it, the rest is pure gold:- 30 FPS cap, although it's expected for an action/adventure PC game to NOT have a fps cap (at least not a game like Dust for example who it's physics engine is based on the 30fps), this cap doesn't make it unplayable at all and I only noticed on the open areas where you can move around the camera freely, so not that bad.- Low Res Shadows, the resolution of shadows are really poor, making me lose the "anime experience" from time to time. The 3D models and cell shading on the other hand were wonderfully implemented.- Low Res Textures, the game represents almost everything as 3D polygons on characters, but the little things that are represented with textures really make the experience off again, like the clouds on the Akatsuki cape when close up.Despite of that, and just because I'm a really graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, the game is marvellous, the effects and animations are epic, never seen a game like this, and the fightings are all filled with action, reflexes and whatnot, and they represented the anime story very well for a video game.Buy it!

Perfect 10/10 must have for a fan of the series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												As a person that hates the Anime for it's lazy and awfully told story line with it's horrid pacing, I really, really, enjoy this game. The story is actually better told here than in the show, and even handles some scenes better than the original since, well, the creators actually knew how to handle the length of the cutscenes. The story itself though is right smack in the middle of everything else though so if you don't know what's been happening from the story from the previous games/anime, the game will not be slowing down to tell you. The game also ends halfway through the biggest fight in the entire series, because, you know, sequals. The gameplay however is surprisingly fun however, it's a basic fighting game formula for half of it, with the one character you have control of fighting off against another, and the other half sort of a hack & slash where you beat on enemies until they die. It's not a difficult game, the only parts that can be called 'hard' are more to a lack of understanding of the mechanics when it throws you into a character/form you haven't handled before (the 9 tails mode at the end was particuliarly annoying.), and this only breeds frustration instead of interesting challenge. The game looks very nice with it's art style, and sounds nice as well. The game performance isn't particuliarly demanding although it certainly wasn't optimized the best for PC, it being a console game and all. The menu's are just really, really, really, bad. Like, really REALLY bad. Theres a loading screen for almost every menu you try to access, and these menu's are unacceptably long for what you're trying to get to. Trying to do a 1vs1 Battle? From the main menu, go to "Quick Battle". Loading screen. From that menu, select the game mode you want. Loading Screen. Pick your character. Loading screen, sometimes 2! There are even loading screens for getting to the timeline in this game.  Do yourself a favour if you're not planning to pay attention to the story and turn the voices from English to Japanese for non cringe voice acting. And bring a 360 controller.

												A fun game if you are a fan of the anime series. There is a lot going on this game and there is so much to do in it such as side events and doing challenging missions to earn more items.10/10 for me but the multiplayer still needs a bit more fixing to do but overall great game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game has great gameplay, visuals and soundtrack but fails to stand out amongst other games of the same series. Many of the charecters feel similar to each other and sometimes combos and ninjutsus are just flashy reskins of their other counterparts  (rasengan, lariat, chidori, raikiri, etc.)The fighting feels good, It's fluid and responsive. Every hit that lands really feels like it hit. When in awakened mode you really feel like you're gaining more power and creating a gap between you and your opponent. Some things are a bit irritating though. Ultimate jutsus take so long to execute even my grandmother has the reflexes to block or evade them. When your block gets broken you stay stunned for way too long. Some of the stages are too big.The story mode is garbage. Sure it has nice visuals but everything feels hollow and empty. There are a bunch of sidequests which include running around the empty world picking up small amounts of money till you get to the fighting part. You beat the fighting part and do a bunch of walking again. Rinse and repeat. This goes for the story mode as well. Walking around the world just to get to the next fight is boring since there isn't anything to explore or experience, it's like waiting in a line and watching a slideshow till you get to the thing you are waiting for. For the price tag of 30€ it's not worth it.+nice visuals, soundtrack and gameplay+it's a Naruto game +good fighting-story mode empty -some things are unbalanced-bad pc port-characters all feel the same -waiting,so much waiting-price

In short, pick this game up if you're a fan of fighting games or the story of Naruto!

												I've played this game for almost 7 hours on record and I have only got past the prologue and the first 3 chapters of the game. There is a total of 10 chapters + Prologue for the campaign which allows you to relive the Naruto Shippuden story from the anime. It starts right after Tendo Pain/Nagato destroys the Hidden Leaf Village up until Naruto fights "Madara Uchiha"/Tobi. There are also 2 other modes called Free Battle and Online Battle(self explanatory). This is the most recent in the Ultimate Ninja Storm franchise as of this review and as an added bonus you get all the DLC along with it. Can't wait for the next instalment "Naruto Shippuden Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution".

												Not only is the game itself worth it for ANY Naruto fan (simply because of how well done it is).But if you buy it on PC, you get to run it in 1080p (or any res you like, 1440p, 4k, etc), you get anti-aliasing, and you get to run it at 60 FPS which makes the experience so much better.Not to mention because it's "Full Burst", you also get all the beautifully re-done cutscenes, all the "DLC" skins for every character, and you get the extra character of Dragon Sage Kabuto + a whole new chapter (the Kabuto vs Uchiha brothers fight).10/10 worth, especially if you get it on sale (which Steam is awesome enough to put it on all the time). I got it when it was half off around June 3rd for a mid-week madness sale, 20 bucks is SO worth for this game.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												An underestimated game that doesn't get the credit and popularity it deserves. This has one of the best fighting mechanics in game, and the cutscenes are very long, deep, and plentiful in plot. They've added lots of original content as well to spice up some of the greater emotional scenes, like Kushina's death. Roster for the game is huge and the online play is alive and kicking well without many cheaters. This is a game that needs to go in everyone's collection if you're a fan of the franchise. If you're simply a fan of fighting games then this is a must have simply for the VS and Online play since the mechanics are so great, and it's VERY fast-paced. The graphics and cutscenes got a huge facelift and upgrade from the previous version of this game, and the PC version's visuals are out of this world. Best damn Naruto game you will ever play. Probably the best anime-based game as well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												PROS: Absolutely spectacular. Cannot recommend highly enough. There's a wealth of depth in the combat system if you care to learn it, but you can also get remarkably far and do remarkably cool things just mashing buttons haphazardly. The story mode is fleshed out superbly with an absolutely staggering amount of voicework from the original Japanese actors (warning, you have to turn Japanese on -- it defaults to the horrendous English actors). So far, I haven't tried VS. mode, but I've unlocked what appear to be an absolute plethora of characters to play. There's also an Online VS. mode which is cool.CONS: The only thing I really dislike about the game is the parts where you're walking around through the village, or through forests, or deserts in an RPG style fashion. The maps are positively gorgeous, and there are hidden treasures to find, but the sluggish speed at which the characters run in these areas really feels awkward with the lightning fast gameplay of the battles and what we've come to know from the show/manga. In battle, Naruto and friends bolt around at amazing speeds we'd expect from ninja -- in the RPG traveling parts, they like... JOG LAZILY. It's really off-putting, and I know it's a weird complaint because the meat of the game is really the fighting, but if I had to pick one complaint about the game, it'd be this.EDIT: A month later, I have to add another con about the game. I am above average at fighting games. I personally found the game's campaign difficult, but never infuriating to the point where I wanted to stop playing. Some fights felt a little cheesy, but never truly unfair. And when there was a DECISION battle, I always took the Legendary (more difficult) route. Toward the very end of the game, there is a Legendary DECISION that, as far as I can tell, is pretty much impossible to beat. There are four-to-five Jinchuuriki ninja beating on you simultaneously. And it'd be one thing if you could perform combos on one of them, but the OTHERS hit and interrupt you -- while you're in the middle of a combo. Just a really stupid fight. I'll admit I'm probably not good enough at the game to beat this particular fight on Legendary, but I never had a real issue with any of the Legendary challenges until this one -- and the gap in difficulty is just absolutely absurd.The game is currently 40% off. I'll admit I had trouble swallowing the $40 price tag, but I've wanted it since it released 6 months ago and I patiently waited until it was on sale. I have to say, if I'd known the game was this good, I would have had NO problem paying full price.Disclaimer: I have to admit, I am a very avid fan of the show and the manga. The game is probably a heck of a lot less exciting if you have never watched it, but I can tell you with confidence that it is still an exceptionally deep and mechanically sound game with gorgeous graphics and the BEST story mode I have ever played in a fighting game.OVERALL: 8/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												To begin, I'm not much of a Naruto fan. Certainly, the series has its merits, but as of yet I've never properly delved into it. All I've seen is the first episode, though I'm fine with taking spoilers and things I don't yet understand in stride.To continue, this game is amazing.Apart from SSB, this is probably the only fighting game I have ever played. The animations are very smooth- the level of detail is nigh impeccable. It has some excellent scenery, from a sunset at the beach to the dark green gloom of ancient ruins. The combat works well, though rather simple. I do kind of wish that they had integrated a similar satisfaction in pulling off team finishers as they did with the ultimate jutsu of each character, since they're harder to pull off. The story is nicely done in the drama department (hit me in the feels more than once), though I kind of wish there was a way to get at some of the backstory- even just including something to read as an option in the menu would have sufficed. My only major complaint with the plot, however, is that the "branching choices" don't seem to really branch out. Basically it all comes down to how much content you want to deal with in one sitting. It's not bad, but it would have been nice to see greater diversity.That's about it- NUNS 3 is a beautiful game that runs surprisingly well. I'm not certain that it's worth full price, but I got it on sale for about eight bucks, which is definitely money well spent. Worth experiencing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
Don't regret it so farA normal gamer would say that this is not their best game bought, but for a Naruto enthusiast like me, it's one of the best games I could have. Pros Hidden Content  Recreate Epic Battles Great, Great, Great Story Mode Make Impossible Battles Happen  Quality is great Very Responsive Controlls  Logitech Controllers Friendly Lots of Content besides the Story ModeCons Online Mode Is Dead Unbalanced (Deidara, Temari, and ranged ninjas can spam ranged skills with no chakra cost) RING OUT - Not really a con, but I don't agree that a ninja can lose like that, if you watch Naruto you will agree with me, but I understand they wanted a different win metaOverall it's a good game, worth it (even if you don't watch Naruto)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												If you love Naruto or you are looking for a fighting game with very nice story telling I recommend all of the Naruto games so far. The games are great in following the anime series and luckily they put focus on the main plot. The visuals fit perfectly and you are able to enjoy this game on japanese. In terms of the fighting itself especially versus others players I wouldn't recommend it. On one side you got plenty of characters to choose from and fighting in 3rd person is a cool experience as well. But on the other side there is way too little variation between the fighters or movesets. Compared to Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat and Tekken you get bored too fast and don't see any point to put much effort in getting better or train a special character. I would have loved environment interaction on the battlefield. For example playing hide and seek in the woods or destroying certain objects with your special moves. Maybe there is more to come in the future. To sum it up, great game for Naruto fans but uninteresting for fighting game lovers only.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Do you like visual novels pretending to be a fighting game?Do you like 30fps and a combat system that is half dynamic action button presses?Do you like watching the loading icon more than playing the actual game?Do you really really really like NarutoIf yes to any of these then this game is for you. I had never played any of the other games in the series but I figured It would be somewhat like mortal kombat, where the characters change as the story progresses. If only it had been more like mortal kombat. If you can manage to bear through the first hour or so of the game it starts to pick up...but what the hell is with the load times, sometimes it feels like the game is mocking you for wanting to, you know, actually play.here is a breakdown of how the game plays.loading screen/cutscene/loding/cutscene/loading/cutscene(yes you can skip them for the most part, however most dont have a dialog skip option so you have to wait for everyone to finish talking)/loading/pre battle planning/FIGHT/loading cutscene/cutscene/loading/walk naruto from one side of the path to the other/loading/loading loading.......I mean come on. Its more of an acion rpg/visual novel than a fighter. which is fine but when you have to load 3 seperate cutscenes before a fight it gets stupid, add on to that you have to load a (free world type) area where you just walk from one side of the screen to the other then it goes back to loading you might as well be putting in seperate disks for each fight, It feels like FFVII level of loading situations.TLDR: loading screen/10

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												My Review:+ Fun Gameplay+ Great storyline+ Huge range of characters+ Tons to do after you complete the main story (took me about 40 hours to complete the main story and the missions)+ Nice graphic style+ Great music (especially in the Prologue)- Some cutscenes are longer than neccessary - There are only two graphics options - resolution and 2x SSAA- 30 FPS cap- The keyboard controls are awful, I strongly reccomend playing with a xbox 360 controller- Online matches are terrible. Every second you get a nice 'transmitting' message and your game will freeze. Overall, the game is definately worth buying if your a fan of Naruto. If you want to avoid spoilers, watch up to the Fourth Shinobi World War: Climax arc. This game does go on sale quite often, so I sugget waiting until then to buy it.

												I am a ♥♥♥♥ing casual at fighting games and as such, I loved this game a lot. (I say this in the most positive way possible)I grew disillusioned with Naruto as the series continued to progress years ago... the anime was chock full of awful filler episodes and keeping updated with the manga became a pain since translators long since abandoned the idea of cleaning up their pages and needlessly insert more fan-art in their entries than actual genuine pages so as such it totally broke the flow of reading a story. This is the best way to experience Naruto without tearing your hair out, the graphics are simple but stylish and the combat is fast and flows comfortably (once you figure it out since the 3rd entry doesn't really provide a tutorial despite being the first entry on PC).Unfortunately however, since this is the 3rd game. The storymode continues on from Storm 2 and since they weren't released for PC you will need to either to have experienced the story so far in another way or risk being overwhelmed and lost in what is going on between the different villiages.Nevertheless, this is a solid game and I home CC2 have the decency to find time to backport Storm 1 and 2.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												The Real Anime FeelI have been a fan of anime for quite some time. Sitting down and exposing yourself to a world of unrestrained possibilities represented through a drawn medium has a certain allure that is irresistible to me. However over the years I have become jaded to games that take on the Anime theme and try to incorporate the style of entertainment into a game. It always just ends up being too gamey, and not flashy enough. I watch anime for the ridiculous fights, and the huge explosions. Both of which are hard to make believable in a fighting game.Quicktime events are littered throughout boss fights and act toenhance combat with impressive sequences and a reactive mini-game.Not that you can't animate them and put a visualization of them in a game. There is just something about the combination of lighting, sound, and color that is very difficult to translate from anime to video game. There are many a Budokai games that in my opinion have failed at this over the years, and left me with a sour taste for games based on anime.Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm by developer CyberConnect 2 tackled this problem and succeeded quite impressively. Every moment you are fighting feels like a moment from the anime, every move you perform feels like it's just the right speed and power. In the beginning combat was so fast that I was mashing the 8 buttons semi-randomly to attempt to keep up. After a while though fighting became fluid and a very satisfying dance between opponents. The fluid motion broken up by staccato flashy "ninjutsu" and ultimate moves that are just as satisfying to pull off as the combat is.The combat itself is very simple. It breaks down to what amounts to a 6 way rock-paper-scissors where the clash of each move is weighed against your opponents and there is a definite advantage given to the winner. The movements are so fast that you have to anticipate what the enemy is about to do in order to gain the upper hand. This leads to a good amount of luck involved in getting the win. There are ways to mitigate the advantages or disadvantages you find yourself in with items and instant teleports which negate the last you took. Combined all these mean that there is a quick learning curve and a low ceiling. The combat is fun and semi-skill based but the real show stopper is the cinematic element that the game presents during each fight.Recreating your favorite fights feels like you arereally stepping into the shoes of your favorite hero/villain.I can't stress enough how much of a treat fighting with your favorite characters is. And there are plenty of characters to choose from. All of them introduced in one way or another in the story mode. This mode is well flushed out and has a lot of the same quirky characteristics of the anime, but doesn't quite go overboard and make things unbelievable. The story mode sticks to the more real and easily presentable scenes and keeps the pace moving quickly from fight to fight. In the end it is just a showcase for many of the characters and fighting modes that are really where the game shines.Really that is what Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm does best. It blends all the great elements of a good game and focuses them into just the one thing, great looking fights between giants. Sound, lighting, blur, animation all serve to enhance this one great aspect of the game. All other things that fall by the way side no longer matter because all you want to do is feel the rush of the next stunning battle. I can forgive a clumsy story/world mode and confusing menu system because it's just so much fun to hop into fight after fight with different teams of ninja to duke it out online and with your friends.Even though story mode isn't that great it still is very pretty.So if you end up picking this series up don't look forward to a great story. Don't look for a wonderfully constructed world to wander around in. Hop into some fights and throw some ultimate moves and get that adrenaline pumping from the insane semi-casual combat. It's easy to get into and fun as hell.You'll like this game if: You enjoy anime and you want to relive some larger than life battles with explosions and a multitude of characters all sporting different abilities. Be warned, a clumsy and short 12 hour story mode will unlock all the characters and get you well versed in the combat. It is well worth it to get into the game. From my blog at: Bigdadgamer.blogspot.com

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												First of all, this review comes from a fan of the series and a fan of PCs, so imagine how happy I'm to be able to play this on my computer.I'll just point out some CONs on the Port (and not the game) I found while playing it, the rest is pure gold:- 30 FPS cap, although it's expected for an action/adventure PC game to NOT have a fps cap (at least not a game like Dust for example who it's physics engine is based on the 30fps), this cap doesn't make it unplayable at all and I only noticed on the open areas where you can move around the camera freely, so not that bad.- Low Res Shadows, the resolution of shadows are really poor, making me lose the "anime experience" from time to time. The 3D models and cell shading on the other hand were wonderfully implemented.- Low Res Textures, the game represents almost everything as 3D polygons on characters, but the little things that are represented with textures really make the experience off again, like the clouds on the Akatsuki cape when close up.Despite of that, and just because I'm a really graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, the game is marvellous, the effects and animations are epic, never seen a game like this, and the fightings are all filled with action, reflexes and whatnot, and they represented the anime story very well for a video game.Buy it!

Posted: January 21, 2015
												I played NS UNS 2 on PS3 and was fascinated by how long a game, which is technically not bringing much changes to the gameplay, can be played (nonstop?!).So when UNS3FB was available for less than 10€, I just HAD to purchase it! And I've not since regretted buying it!When I first wanted to start playing, I was irritated, I have no controller for PC and there are no standard settings for playing with keyboard, so the first thing you gotta do is configurate your keybindings.When I started playing then, I was surprised how "normal" the difficulty was (thought it would be hell without controller).Fights are (so far) not hard to win, but that's gonna change for sure later (at least I'll/you'll have problems with S-Ranks).There are slight changes in the gameplay though (e.g. no items usable without a fight, only way to replenish health is either Ichiraku or bentos).Well, all in all I am happy I took the chance to play it for not much money, though eventually I would pay the full price now (if I hadn't used that opportunity)

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												If you like anime, Naruto, button masher and cel shader, grab this one!Campaign is a very nice story adaption and not too hard. Playing it through unlocks all characters, too (takes less than 30h if you watch all scenes and hunt for rank S). But for unlocking, MP will work, too, as every fight rewards you with some money and unlocking works by gaining total amount X for each character and outfit.Multiplayer works good: local 2 player, turnament mode for up to 8 player, online battles and is relativerly good balanced so far.Fighting style is the most important, at least for me:You don't have to remember tons of combos like in Tekken or Mortal combat; there are some general combos working for every character and if you have your favourite, there are 3-4 more for each character; but you don't loose just because you don't know them by heart. Most of the time you 'just' have to react fast and correct instead of hammering 10-varying-button-combos.That makes it also a nice alternative for party games like Smash Brothers since it's relatively easy to learn, only mastering takes some time.

												First off, this game is not for you if you're not interested in Naruto.Story mode is decent. It gets boring sometimes, but it's overall very interesting, mostly fun to play, and sometimes even emotional. I (kind of) cried twice playing this game. That came close to the record set by KH2, which means it's pretty emotional. It's also more or less 99% canonical (except for the last few sequences) , which is a great improvement over earlier Naruto games.The combat's... well, pretty good. I didn't play any previous versions of Storm so I have nothing to compare to, but the battle mode is fun except that it will get boring if you play with the AI all the time. The freeroaming bandits are more often annoying than anything else.It's a tad overpriced, but overall worth it. I f you're a Naruto fan, put it in your wishlist and get it during a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game has great gameplay, visuals and soundtrack but fails to stand out amongst other games of the same series. Many of the charecters feel similar to each other and sometimes combos and ninjutsus are just flashy reskins of their other counterparts  (rasengan, lariat, chidori, raikiri, etc.)The fighting feels good, It's fluid and responsive. Every hit that lands really feels like it hit. When in awakened mode you really feel like you're gaining more power and creating a gap between you and your opponent. Some things are a bit irritating though. Ultimate jutsus take so long to execute even my grandmother has the reflexes to block or evade them. When your block gets broken you stay stunned for way too long. Some of the stages are too big.The story mode is garbage. Sure it has nice visuals but everything feels hollow and empty. There are a bunch of sidequests which include running around the empty world picking up small amounts of money till you get to the fighting part. You beat the fighting part and do a bunch of walking again. Rinse and repeat. This goes for the story mode as well. Walking around the world just to get to the next fight is boring since there isn't anything to explore or experience, it's like waiting in a line and watching a slideshow till you get to the thing you are waiting for. For the price tag of 30€ it's not worth it.+nice visuals, soundtrack and gameplay+it's a Naruto game +good fighting-story mode empty -some things are unbalanced-bad pc port-characters all feel the same -waiting,so much waiting-price

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												As a person that hates the Anime for it's lazy and awfully told story line with it's horrid pacing, I really, really, enjoy this game. The story is actually better told here than in the show, and even handles some scenes better than the original since, well, the creators actually knew how to handle the length of the cutscenes. The story itself though is right smack in the middle of everything else though so if you don't know what's been happening from the story from the previous games/anime, the game will not be slowing down to tell you. The game also ends halfway through the biggest fight in the entire series, because, you know, sequals. The gameplay however is surprisingly fun however, it's a basic fighting game formula for half of it, with the one character you have control of fighting off against another, and the other half sort of a hack & slash where you beat on enemies until they die. It's not a difficult game, the only parts that can be called 'hard' are more to a lack of understanding of the mechanics when it throws you into a character/form you haven't handled before (the 9 tails mode at the end was particuliarly annoying.), and this only breeds frustration instead of interesting challenge. The game looks very nice with it's art style, and sounds nice as well. The game performance isn't particuliarly demanding although it certainly wasn't optimized the best for PC, it being a console game and all. The menu's are just really, really, really, bad. Like, really REALLY bad. Theres a loading screen for almost every menu you try to access, and these menu's are unacceptably long for what you're trying to get to. Trying to do a 1vs1 Battle? From the main menu, go to "Quick Battle". Loading screen. From that menu, select the game mode you want. Loading Screen. Pick your character. Loading screen, sometimes 2! There are even loading screens for getting to the timeline in this game.  Do yourself a favour if you're not planning to pay attention to the story and turn the voices from English to Japanese for non cringe voice acting. And bring a 360 controller.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm 3, in my humble opinion, is a really fun game with a few flaws keeping it from greatness. As an avid fan of the series both manga and anime, I decided to pick this game up after doing some research on it, and have been very pleased. Disclaimer: This is my first ever Gamefaqs review; you have been warnedGraphics: 9/10I think that the game is just beautiful! The character models are all rendered and match their anime counterparts nicely. While the graphics don't look exactly like the anime, I think thats a good thing. because it looks like a video game instead.As you fight through the story, you will face a wide variety of characters, fight huge bosses, and you will get to visit a multitude of iconic locations from the series. Not one time in my playthrough did I say "well that doesn't look very good." The color, scenery, and vividness of the game really do an excellent job of capturing the Naruto Universe that we all know and love. Even the opening menus have a great amount of detail put into them.Another big part of this game is the large, large, LARGE amount of cutscenes and action sequences, and I believe that they all look fantastic! There are massive explosions, high paced action, and gripping story moments that are all captured very well within the games engine. However, there is at least one major fault, and its mainly because the game can get a little big for its britches sometimes. I don't think I experienced this at all throughout the story, but when playing in tournaments or online, if multiple jutsus and teammates start getting called, the game does have framerate issues. This is the sole reason this portion doesn't get a 10 from me.Story: 8/10Now, if we are just talking Naruto as the manga, I would personally give this a 10; but we're not, we are talking about Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 the game, and it does have some setbacks.The game follows the story immediatley after Naruto's confrontation with Pain, and continues up almost to where the manga is currently. The main form of story progression is through cutscenes, which there are a ton of! Not that that is bad though. One cutscene in particular lasts at least 30 minutes, but it does a wonderful job of getting you immmersed in the story and if you are invested in the series (like me) you may even find yoursef shedding a tear or two! How many times can you say a video game has done that to you before?My biggest qualm with the story has to do with the so called "Ultimate Decisions" you make throughout the game, as they really don't do anything to effect the way that the plot unfolds. I think that in theory it was a good idea, but basically all it does is ramp up the difficulty (slightly) on certain missions. UNS3 is not a difficult game to begin with, and I would have rather seen two different endings than come to the same road at the end for some additional replay value.The story also expects you to already know what is going on, so if you are on the fence about getting this and don't know your Naruto lore study it up or you will not have a clue about what's going on.Sound: 8/10Not much to say here. I thought that the music fit the mood for the game very nicely. Sad moments had soft piano keys playing in the background, and intense moments revved it up the way you would expect a Naruto game to. Everything in between was pleasant to listen to, it's just... it wasn't the original soundtrack. As much attention to detail as was put into everything else, I really wish they had gone ahead and gotten it, because you just can't replace it. I guess there were some copyright issues preventing its use.Gameplay: 8/10A cast of over 80 characters unite for some seriously over the top action that you can take on in the story mode, locally with friends, or online against the rest of the world! This game is so much fun to play! So why does it get an eight instead of 10, I will explain. One downside is the very limited free roam that is offered. I almost thought why even include it, but it does open up from otherwise linear paths after you have completed the story. Basically sometimes you will watch a cutscene, then get sent to free roam. After running a short ways you will then enter another cutscene or battle. There is really not much to it other than that. You can talk to NPC's and there are a few sidequest offered, but they really didn't seem worth it to me unless you are going for all of the trophies. It is mainly just a means to an end to get you to the next battle. And that is where the meat of the game is anyway, the battles.The game has both single and team battles. Single being just you as your character of choice (or who is currently the story character), while team battle allows you to pick one or two support characters to help you. The combat is fast paced, but never too difficult to follow, with exceptions being online sometimes. You primarily attack with the circle button, or B button if you are on Xbox, and have three varying combos you can perform by just pressing circle and using the analog stick. Triangle is your chakra load button, X is jump, and square is the shuriken button. You have basic, and chakra loaded moves that you can execute by pressing the chakra button followed by a different command. This is how you execute your jutsu and ultimate jutsu attacks. You can also block by holding R2, though it can be broken, and you can use a substitution jutsu by pressing L2 while being attacked.There are a variety of cancels that you can perform when executing attacks that will allow you to create your own, flashier combos, and add some depth to the gameplay. The most common of these is the Chakra Dash Cancel (CDC). Basically, while comboing or doing another action, you can press triangle and then X immediatly after to cancel whatever you were currently doing. These cancels are what really add the tactical aspects to battles, as well as providing ways to score big damage if you know what your doing.All that being said, you will have a blast playing through the story mode, but you may experience frustration if you try to take the game online.For me, it has mainly been connection issues. Lag is very, very abusable in this game. I cannot tell you how many times I have eaten a jutsu because the game read one extra circle press. Basically, when you are fighting someone online you need to conserve your chakra and your substitution jutsus more than anything. Play well, make the other guy run out of substitutes, and then punish them with big damage, thats how its supposed to go. However, get into a room with a little bit of input lag, and your read on when your opponent is going to substitue turns into a Rasengan Barrage because instead of being able to block or chakra cancel, the game said you hit attack again. It is playable though, and playing in rooms with little lag is a lot of fun. Winning against a good opponent is a very rewarding experience, not to mention you get to do all with your favorite Naruto characters! Both ranked and player matches are offered, as well as a tournament mode that I haven't gotten to try yet, but has a variety of different rules.I would also have liked for this game to have been made with a more competitive aspect to it rather than almost strictly fanservice and casual. There is a skill aspect to it, some players are simply going to be better than you should you pick up the game, but there are some mechanics, like awakenings, that I do not like. Awakenings are very powerful "super modes" that characters can enter. Don't get me wrong, they look AWESOME and make you feel like a boss when you use them, but they need to go IMO. You could be playing the match of your life, and have your opponent down to half a bar left, but if they manage to get their awakening off they could easily turn the tide back in their favor, and I do not like mechanics that reward players for getting beaten. Instant awakening

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												For a fan of the Naruto series this game is excellent, it tells the story brilliantly with fully voice acted (Japanese and English) cutscenes throughout which is very impressive considering the amount of dialogue and cutscenes in the game. It is mostly faithful to the anime and manga (with the exception of the final fight which I assume was changed to give the game a climactic ending opposed to just continuing as the anime does). However, there is a huge amount of assumed knowledge about the series. The story of this game cannot be fully appreciated unless you have seen a good amount of Shippuden and in places it references things that happened in the original series without bothering to give you a reminder or fill in those who havnt seen it. The story often takes presidence over gameplay with quicktime events mid-fight with actions representing the fights in the anime.The combat is what you would expect from an anime spectacle fighter, with alot of charging up attacks, cinematic grapples and finishers. If you enjoy this type of fighting game, then this is one of the best. However, the powers of individual characters seem to be faithful to the series as opposed to being fairly balanced for online multiplayer. For example Madara with annihalate characters like Sakura with ease (however its not nearly as bad as older Dragonball Z games where some characters could 1-shot others).Overall, for a fan of the Naruto series this game is excellent. However, if you're the type of person to skip cutscenes, dont bother as this game isn't affraid of throwing 40 minute cutscenes your way (not an exageration, the Minato/Kushina flashback midway through the game is around 40 minutes long). The story took me 12 hours to complete including the full burst Kabuto fights, 7-8 hours of which is cutscenes. Regardless, the free-battles and multi-player have so far given me an additional 6 hours and counting.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game has great gameplay, visuals and soundtrack but fails to stand out amongst other games of the same series. Many of the charecters feel similar to each other and sometimes combos and ninjutsus are just flashy reskins of their other counterparts  (rasengan, lariat, chidori, raikiri, etc.)The fighting feels good, It's fluid and responsive. Every hit that lands really feels like it hit. When in awakened mode you really feel like you're gaining more power and creating a gap between you and your opponent. Some things are a bit irritating though. Ultimate jutsus take so long to execute even my grandmother has the reflexes to block or evade them. When your block gets broken you stay stunned for way too long. Some of the stages are too big.The story mode is garbage. Sure it has nice visuals but everything feels hollow and empty. There are a bunch of sidequests which include running around the empty world picking up small amounts of money till you get to the fighting part. You beat the fighting part and do a bunch of walking again. Rinse and repeat. This goes for the story mode as well. Walking around the world just to get to the next fight is boring since there isn't anything to explore or experience, it's like waiting in a line and watching a slideshow till you get to the thing you are waiting for. For the price tag of 30€ it's not worth it.+nice visuals, soundtrack and gameplay+it's a Naruto game +good fighting-story mode empty -some things are unbalanced-bad pc port-characters all feel the same -waiting,so much waiting-price
