number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												The Real Anime FeelI have been a fan of anime for quite some time. Sitting down and exposing yourself to a world of unrestrained possibilities represented through a drawn medium has a certain allure that is irresistible to me. However over the years I have become jaded to games that take on the Anime theme and try to incorporate the style of entertainment into a game. It always just ends up being too gamey, and not flashy enough. I watch anime for the ridiculous fights, and the huge explosions. Both of which are hard to make believable in a fighting game.Quicktime events are littered throughout boss fights and act toenhance combat with impressive sequences and a reactive mini-game.Not that you can't animate them and put a visualization of them in a game. There is just something about the combination of lighting, sound, and color that is very difficult to translate from anime to video game. There are many a Budokai games that in my opinion have failed at this over the years, and left me with a sour taste for games based on anime.Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm by developer CyberConnect 2 tackled this problem and succeeded quite impressively. Every moment you are fighting feels like a moment from the anime, every move you perform feels like it's just the right speed and power. In the beginning combat was so fast that I was mashing the 8 buttons semi-randomly to attempt to keep up. After a while though fighting became fluid and a very satisfying dance between opponents. The fluid motion broken up by staccato flashy "ninjutsu" and ultimate moves that are just as satisfying to pull off as the combat is.The combat itself is very simple. It breaks down to what amounts to a 6 way rock-paper-scissors where the clash of each move is weighed against your opponents and there is a definite advantage given to the winner. The movements are so fast that you have to anticipate what the enemy is about to do in order to gain the upper hand. This leads to a good amount of luck involved in getting the win. There are ways to mitigate the advantages or disadvantages you find yourself in with items and instant teleports which negate the last you took. Combined all these mean that there is a quick learning curve and a low ceiling. The combat is fun and semi-skill based but the real show stopper is the cinematic element that the game presents during each fight.Recreating your favorite fights feels like you arereally stepping into the shoes of your favorite hero/villain.I can't stress enough how much of a treat fighting with your favorite characters is. And there are plenty of characters to choose from. All of them introduced in one way or another in the story mode. This mode is well flushed out and has a lot of the same quirky characteristics of the anime, but doesn't quite go overboard and make things unbelievable. The story mode sticks to the more real and easily presentable scenes and keeps the pace moving quickly from fight to fight. In the end it is just a showcase for many of the characters and fighting modes that are really where the game shines.Really that is what Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm does best. It blends all the great elements of a good game and focuses them into just the one thing, great looking fights between giants. Sound, lighting, blur, animation all serve to enhance this one great aspect of the game. All other things that fall by the way side no longer matter because all you want to do is feel the rush of the next stunning battle. I can forgive a clumsy story/world mode and confusing menu system because it's just so much fun to hop into fight after fight with different teams of ninja to duke it out online and with your friends.Even though story mode isn't that great it still is very pretty.So if you end up picking this series up don't look forward to a great story. Don't look for a wonderfully constructed world to wander around in. Hop into some fights and throw some ultimate moves and get that adrenaline pumping from the insane semi-casual combat. It's easy to get into and fun as hell.You'll like this game if: You enjoy anime and you want to relive some larger than life battles with explosions and a multitude of characters all sporting different abilities. Be warned, a clumsy and short 12 hour story mode will unlock all the characters and get you well versed in the combat. It is well worth it to get into the game. From my blog at: Bigdadgamer.blogspot.com

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												- In short: A surprisingly good and robust game!- Extended version: I wasn't sure what to expect from this title. I bought it during the summer sale, for the sake of having at least one actual anime-title in my library. I started it, because it actually went beyond the constant recycling of the older content,but once I started the game I was surprised by how nice it plays (provided you own a gamepad) and how...fun the game is.The story provides good variety in terms of combat, letting you play with various characters "as the story happened.",so you're not stuck with just naruto, nor are you allowed to pick a character of your own. You have to play with the hand you're dealt...and that's a good thing.Aside from the standard combat, there are also deviations, giving you epic set pieces when you are fighting a boss (like the 9-tails, for example) or you can be pitted against multiple enemies at once.The variety in combat style is a great way to change the pace and it keeps you interested.Then there are the Simon-says button-matching sequences which - contrary to how it usually tend to work - are actually quite awesome: if you mess up, you die; you do a decent job, you pass; you do a good job, you even get a little extra.The computer AI also deserves some praise. Usually you can set the difficulty yourself, but this time you either deal with it, or pick the less-dangerous option when available. Regardless, the AI can be quite tricky at times, giving even seasoned gamers a run for their money.My main problem with this game is that there are also collectibles of sorts. As such, you are granted the freedom to roam about between each fight, which pulls you away from the story. As you are essentially watching the anime you are suddenly put back in the shoes of whichever character you are controlling, simply running from A to B in order to progress, picking up a hand-full of cash along the way.I understand this is done in order to grant people the sense they have the ability to roam about and to get their achievements, but you are not all that free, nor does it feel like a truly relevant "system". You really ARE just running from A to B. but even then, I suppose it can be forgiven.Aside from the story there are you classic Vs. battles again the AI, another person sitting next to you, or even someone sitting on the other side of the internet. Duke it out in a tournament style, or just a 1-on-1 match with the ability to have helper characters or not. Sporting a massive roster (the majority of which are various "modes" of characters and characters for the sake of nostalgia) there is plenty to go about and some of the characters truly feel unique in terms of maneuvrability. Some of the characters are true long-distance fighters, whilst others come to live in some classic CQC.As far as visual presentation goes: I tip my hat.While you can still clearly see the difference between the actual anime and the game...the game comes damn close to the real thing. Vibrant, flashy colors and a true sense of over-the-top-ness makes for a lush and pleasing presentation that'll leave you wanting for more.The music left no real lingering impression on me, but it feel Naruto-esque, if anything.All in all: if you are a fan of the anime and have been pondering whether or not to get this game: I suggest you give this a try...you might be in for a pleasant surprise.I'd say the same for someone ignorant to this series, but you really do fall right in the middle of things and there are strong references to the anime, aside from the fact that this game closely follows the actual manga/anime (if that makes sense)If you ARE in fact a newcomer...perhaps read into the events prior to this title and try this game regardless.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm 3, in my humble opinion, is a really fun game with a few flaws keeping it from greatness. As an avid fan of the series both manga and anime, I decided to pick this game up after doing some research on it, and have been very pleased. Disclaimer: This is my first ever Gamefaqs review; you have been warnedGraphics: 9/10I think that the game is just beautiful! The character models are all rendered and match their anime counterparts nicely. While the graphics don't look exactly like the anime, I think thats a good thing. because it looks like a video game instead.As you fight through the story, you will face a wide variety of characters, fight huge bosses, and you will get to visit a multitude of iconic locations from the series. Not one time in my playthrough did I say "well that doesn't look very good." The color, scenery, and vividness of the game really do an excellent job of capturing the Naruto Universe that we all know and love. Even the opening menus have a great amount of detail put into them.Another big part of this game is the large, large, LARGE amount of cutscenes and action sequences, and I believe that they all look fantastic! There are massive explosions, high paced action, and gripping story moments that are all captured very well within the games engine. However, there is at least one major fault, and its mainly because the game can get a little big for its britches sometimes. I don't think I experienced this at all throughout the story, but when playing in tournaments or online, if multiple jutsus and teammates start getting called, the game does have framerate issues. This is the sole reason this portion doesn't get a 10 from me.Story: 8/10Now, if we are just talking Naruto as the manga, I would personally give this a 10; but we're not, we are talking about Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 the game, and it does have some setbacks.The game follows the story immediatley after Naruto's confrontation with Pain, and continues up almost to where the manga is currently. The main form of story progression is through cutscenes, which there are a ton of! Not that that is bad though. One cutscene in particular lasts at least 30 minutes, but it does a wonderful job of getting you immmersed in the story and if you are invested in the series (like me) you may even find yoursef shedding a tear or two! How many times can you say a video game has done that to you before?My biggest qualm with the story has to do with the so called "Ultimate Decisions" you make throughout the game, as they really don't do anything to effect the way that the plot unfolds. I think that in theory it was a good idea, but basically all it does is ramp up the difficulty (slightly) on certain missions. UNS3 is not a difficult game to begin with, and I would have rather seen two different endings than come to the same road at the end for some additional replay value.The story also expects you to already know what is going on, so if you are on the fence about getting this and don't know your Naruto lore study it up or you will not have a clue about what's going on.Sound: 8/10Not much to say here. I thought that the music fit the mood for the game very nicely. Sad moments had soft piano keys playing in the background, and intense moments revved it up the way you would expect a Naruto game to. Everything in between was pleasant to listen to, it's just... it wasn't the original soundtrack. As much attention to detail as was put into everything else, I really wish they had gone ahead and gotten it, because you just can't replace it. I guess there were some copyright issues preventing its use.Gameplay: 8/10A cast of over 80 characters unite for some seriously over the top action that you can take on in the story mode, locally with friends, or online against the rest of the world! This game is so much fun to play! So why does it get an eight instead of 10, I will explain. One downside is the very limited free roam that is offered. I almost thought why even include it, but it does open up from otherwise linear paths after you have completed the story. Basically sometimes you will watch a cutscene, then get sent to free roam. After running a short ways you will then enter another cutscene or battle. There is really not much to it other than that. You can talk to NPC's and there are a few sidequest offered, but they really didn't seem worth it to me unless you are going for all of the trophies. It is mainly just a means to an end to get you to the next battle. And that is where the meat of the game is anyway, the battles.The game has both single and team battles. Single being just you as your character of choice (or who is currently the story character), while team battle allows you to pick one or two support characters to help you. The combat is fast paced, but never too difficult to follow, with exceptions being online sometimes. You primarily attack with the circle button, or B button if you are on Xbox, and have three varying combos you can perform by just pressing circle and using the analog stick. Triangle is your chakra load button, X is jump, and square is the shuriken button. You have basic, and chakra loaded moves that you can execute by pressing the chakra button followed by a different command. This is how you execute your jutsu and ultimate jutsu attacks. You can also block by holding R2, though it can be broken, and you can use a substitution jutsu by pressing L2 while being attacked.There are a variety of cancels that you can perform when executing attacks that will allow you to create your own, flashier combos, and add some depth to the gameplay. The most common of these is the Chakra Dash Cancel (CDC). Basically, while comboing or doing another action, you can press triangle and then X immediatly after to cancel whatever you were currently doing. These cancels are what really add the tactical aspects to battles, as well as providing ways to score big damage if you know what your doing.All that being said, you will have a blast playing through the story mode, but you may experience frustration if you try to take the game online.For me, it has mainly been connection issues. Lag is very, very abusable in this game. I cannot tell you how many times I have eaten a jutsu because the game read one extra circle press. Basically, when you are fighting someone online you need to conserve your chakra and your substitution jutsus more than anything. Play well, make the other guy run out of substitutes, and then punish them with big damage, thats how its supposed to go. However, get into a room with a little bit of input lag, and your read on when your opponent is going to substitue turns into a Rasengan Barrage because instead of being able to block or chakra cancel, the game said you hit attack again. It is playable though, and playing in rooms with little lag is a lot of fun. Winning against a good opponent is a very rewarding experience, not to mention you get to do all with your favorite Naruto characters! Both ranked and player matches are offered, as well as a tournament mode that I haven't gotten to try yet, but has a variety of different rules.I would also have liked for this game to have been made with a more competitive aspect to it rather than almost strictly fanservice and casual. There is a skill aspect to it, some players are simply going to be better than you should you pick up the game, but there are some mechanics, like awakenings, that I do not like. Awakenings are very powerful "super modes" that characters can enter. Don't get me wrong, they look AWESOME and make you feel like a boss when you use them, but they need to go IMO. You could be playing the match of your life, and have your opponent down to half a bar left, but if they manage to get their awakening off they could easily turn the tide back in their favor, and I do not like mechanics that reward players for getting beaten. Instant awakening

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												I can recommend it - but *only* if you do not mind to handle inventory and item stuff - which for me is too much micromanagement. After losing health in a fight, you *will* have to manually refill it yourself.I expected something a little bit different.The story and atmosphere is great. Seeing the Konoha universe from this very new, dynamic and 3D perspective is great. But the missing game mechanics introduction and all-text tips and tutorials (that take you out of the interactive game and 3d display - really suck.Knowing a bit about technology and thinking about usability, I think it could have been a lot better as well. I want to play, and I am impatient in that matter - when the saving takes pretty long, and it then shows a "saved" notification for another 1.5 seconds - that's so unecessary, and for me frustrating (yeah, you can call it nitpicking. I’m that nitpicky and thoughtful about my products as well.).What I would have wanted, is this game but with an in-game interactive tutorial, and without shopping and items, searching for money on the ground and very selectively placed, destructable debris.A game that let’s you play the action and free-roaming sections and has great cutscenes, but does not take you out of the action through text boxes, too much introductory information (game mechanics seem too complex). And I certainly do not want to manage an inventory, and have to refresh my health through buying meals and items to drink.You can absolutely see that it is a port from a console game. Fixed, low max FPS, few settings, unnecessarily long loading times. It does seem perfectly playable though. So it is a port of not much effort, but very reasonable - stable and performant.Sadly, I stopped playing because of the aforementioned item system. I am at a fight where I would have to heal and probably know a bit more game mechanics - but I just want to actually play the game, and not be forced to go back.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												So.... I used to be a Naruto watcher. I loved Naruto... Naruto was my introduction to the anime world in my early teen years. So I'm biast. UN Storm is amazing in so many ways. 1. Its visually stricking.This game has such a great looking over-world. When you're Naruto walking in the Hidden Leaf Village, theres kids catching bugs, people socializing, and dogs running around... it's one of the most dynamic over-worlds I've ever experienced. Its not just NPC's standing in groups with dialog above them, it's like a real world.2. The gameplay.Its ALSO visually stricking! and I think that's one of the most important things about a fighting game. A bad looking fighting game to me, is a bad game. Visuals are a very important thing to me where skill isn't the most prevelent part of the game. Theres at most 3 combos, 2 ninjutsu, 1 throw, black and evade like in any fighting game, but the simplicity of the game itself is its own strength. This game very well could be the gateway drug to fighting games. 3. The story.Oh god... so nestalgic. I've never finished watching Naruto because I started watching other anime and Naruto was over 150 episodes... I didn't have time to lock down on one anime and plus TOONAMI ENDED ON CARTOON NETWORK WHICH CAUSED ME TO HAVE SEVERE NIGHT TERRORS FOR THE PAST 3 YEARS. Finally playing through this game and seeing the end of Naruto Shippuden was very.. very nestalgic. I almost shed a tear. Almost. Its a good game. and its only 10 dollars. If you have any affinity to the Naruto franchise, you owe it to yourself to own and play this game, even if you've finished the anime.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												The only way I recommend this game is if you are a die-hard Naruto fan (have watched/read/played the story up to this point) and have either played previous games in this series before or are up for a bit of reading and experimenting with controls.That said, here are the reasons I do not recommend this game to everyone else:NS:UNS3FB (even as a acronym it's a mouthful) is a fighting game with three modes: Story, which picks up around book 50 of the Naruto manga, after the attack on Konoha (um, the second one) and goes to the heat of the Fourth Great Ninja War. From what I have heard, the game actually makes up its own ending to this, which will probably cause confusion when the fourth game in the series comes around, but I'm not concerned with that.See, this game is not a game for beginners, and this is my greatest beef with it. There are no tutorials in story mode. There are just about 25 dialogue boxes that display tips for the game - and you can't even access the start menu to view them until after the first few battles! So yes, if you haven't played the previous games (which are not on Steam currently) prepare to experiment a bit. Even then, you may get the feeling of missing out on things, watering down the experience. As I understand the battle system right now, it's only okay. There are items you can use... but that's not really my play style. Plus there are a TON of them to unlock, so I just ignore them completely. I've never needed any of them yet.This brand of xenophobia towards newbies continues with the story itself. No explanations are given for past events, nor is any glossary given for the Naruto lexicon that has built up over the past 10+ years. There is a timeline that allows you to view key events from before the game, but I am halfway into story mode and have not yet unlocked a single one of those events.And the cutscenes. Yikes. I haven't compared them, but the story mode likely covers most, if not all scenes from the manga. This means a lot of content, nearly all voiced and paced accordingly. The story has its moments, yes (Naruto meeting his mother in Chapter 4 had me tear up, honestly), but you will come to realize quickly that you will spend around 4/5ths of your time in story mode watching cutscenes and the rest actually controlling your character. It gives Final Fantasy VII: Dirge of Cerberus a run for its money. Each chapter roughly consists of about 5 1-3 minute stages... and then an hour's worth of scenes. This is odd. Other Naruto games have managed story better - I'm thinking of the early Clash of Ninjas, and maybe even the original Ultimate Ninja games, although I remember those less. I've finally wised up and started skipping scenes.There is an overworld, or should I say a collection of straight paths which try to resemble an overworld. Besides Konoha, which you only spend a bit of time in, the overworld portions seem pointless, and are basically only hubs in which to shop and save your game before going to your next fight - menus could have done them equally as well.There are thousands of collectibles to buy, but most of these are titles and still images you can use to spruce up your ninja info card for online play. Unless you are a absolutely hardcore completionist, you'll probably just buy the ones you want and get on with it. If you can find them - ever try navigating a drop-down style menu with 1000 options? You're going to.The second mode is simply free battle. It's straightforward. Naruto Shippuden has a large roster (around 100 off the top of my head), and you'll probably find your favorites here. Many have alternate costumes/forms which may or may not be considered separate characters. Most of the characters have to be unlocked from story mode, though. For Full Burst there is also a 100-mission mission mode. I've heard gripes that not every character from Story mode is playable, but with a good-sized roster already, I have no problem with that.The third mode is online play. I have not tested this, but I assume it plays more or less akin to Free Battle. With other people. And there's rankings.I remember seeing a screenshot in a magazine for the first Storm game long ago and being blown away by how true to the anime it looked. Here, backgrounds look good, but character outlines ruin the setup a bit, I think. Still decent, though.SUMMARY: Unforgiving to beginners in controls or story, and catering to fans moreso than newcomers, NS:UNS3FB is ok, but fails to stand up to the great fighter games, or even other Naruto games.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This game seriously surprised me in how much I loved it. The game is an adventure fighting game. There are some RPG elements as well. The combat is pretty easy to get a grasp on but it has really great game feel. As you progress through the story mode you play as a wide variety of characters each with vastly different fighting styles. The main mechanic of the game is that all the fighting moves are performed with the same simple button combinations, but each attack for the different characters has different effects, ranges, and even uses. It is interesting.The main story mode take a good while to get through especially if you watch all the cut scenes. I'd say at least 10-12 hours. The story is the only problem with the game. If you are not familiar with the world of Naruto you will be lost here. This game features more characters than Game of Thrones and you will only know their significance if you have watched the Anime to some extent. I know I quit watching the show around episode 100, I knew who most of the characters were but a lot of the politics and newer characters went over my head. Still it is an interesting story, and well acted and extremely well animated. The game looks just like the show it is amazing at times.

												Unplayable on certain GPU's. Worked fine on my Radeon HD 6950 1GB, but with my much newer, much better Radeon R9 290 4GB, it is almost completely unplayable. From what I've gathered online, the game is so badly optimized, it's not compatible with clock speeds that are too high. There are work arounds, but they can wear down, or even damage your GPU, and shorten its lifespan. I wouldn't hold out hope for a patch either. If you want to get it, try looking around the web if your GPU is compatible.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												If somebody told me last year that I would not only play this game, but own it; I would have laughed in their face. You see, I'm not an avid Naruto fan. In fact, I find the idea idiotic. Ninjas that run around screaming their attacks while wearing bright and revealing clothing? Not very appealing to me (Most anime isn't). However, I was introduced to this game on the PS3 by a roommate of mine. He knew I liked games like Soul Calibur and Super Smash Bros, so he told me I HAD to try this. Well, here I am, six months later, owning it on the PC. The gameplay is probably one of the best systems for a fighting game and the controls are superb when using an Xbox controller. The graphics are beautiful and clear. However, because of the impressive visuals, you're going to need a pretty good PC to run this well. The gameplay works like an extremely fast paced and more strategic yet simplified version of Soul Calibur. There is no confusing button combonations to destroy your opponent, but instead all attacks are keyed to one button while pressing a different button a different amount of times changes what kind of attack you do. The story is alright (Like I said, not a fan of the series), and the voice acting is not anything to be impressed by (Rather painful in places). However, the one terrible and good thing about the game is the cutscenes. It plays like a movie when you aren't interacting. Sometimes it is enjoyable to watch; other times it drags out way too long. Another negative is the online multiplayer. From my understanding, it used to be worse than it is already. The only thing that gets in the way is the connection signals. The rounds lag from beginning to end and it is very difficult to actually find a person to fight. Once you do find someone who doesn't lag and is willing to fight, you tend to stay with that guy and keep fighting him rather than try finding another person.The only bug I have encountered in this game is one that could be considered a major annoyance. It tends to crash during local multiplayer battles. At the menu, choosing characters, sometimes even in the battle itself, the game crashes and shuts down. There is a fix however: play it in windowed mode. It does not really detract from game play and keeps it from crashing.All in all, I give a positive review of a game I thought I would never play. The gods of video games and anime must have conspired to create a video game of an anime I despise and make it as amazing as possible so I would get it. Get this game when it goes on sale (because it definitely will). I got it a few months after being ported to the PC and got it for $5 instead of $55; total steal!9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Being a fan of the 'Clash of Ninja' series I was really excited to play this Ninja storm series mainly because its on computer. Although this game has the best story i've seen in a "fighting" game and its also very well polished I do find myself dissapointed in the combat mechanics.You only have 1 ninjutsu and 1 ultimate ninjutsu per charecter. Along with a simple combo system I tend to get bored of each charecter quickly. Instead of quailty ninja with a variety of abilites they made a lot of the same ninja but with alternate  2 ninjutsu's for a overall higher number of ninja on the box. Theres about 4 or 5 different Naruto's and Sauske's to choose from all being about the same just 1 or 2 different abilities and costume. Also theres no 2v2 or survival mode. Huge dissapointment if you have friends over. Your only option is to fight against your friend you can never fight WITH them like in Clash of Ninja. The main reasons this game is better then Clash is for its Story mode and how it runs perfect on my computer. The Wii can't run a Naruto game without slowing down from the graphics, maybe the Wii-U could do it. I'm going to finish this game mainly for the story but i've yet to find a ninja I like to play more then one battle at a time =\

Posted: January 21, 2015
												I played NS UNS 2 on PS3 and was fascinated by how long a game, which is technically not bringing much changes to the gameplay, can be played (nonstop?!).So when UNS3FB was available for less than 10€, I just HAD to purchase it! And I've not since regretted buying it!When I first wanted to start playing, I was irritated, I have no controller for PC and there are no standard settings for playing with keyboard, so the first thing you gotta do is configurate your keybindings.When I started playing then, I was surprised how "normal" the difficulty was (thought it would be hell without controller).Fights are (so far) not hard to win, but that's gonna change for sure later (at least I'll/you'll have problems with S-Ranks).There are slight changes in the gameplay though (e.g. no items usable without a fight, only way to replenish health is either Ichiraku or bentos).Well, all in all I am happy I took the chance to play it for not much money, though eventually I would pay the full price now (if I hadn't used that opportunity)

Some spoilers may be shown hereFirst of all, this game has an awesome storyline, however a lot of it is made up of cutscenes. If you think of it as watching TV, it's alright. The battling and the camera angles are perfect. The free battling is a lot of fun. I'm currently  halfway through versing Tobi, the 7 Jinchuriki and the Taile Beasts, which I think is pretty hard for 1 health bar. The online play needs some fixing as it is really laggy, even when I try doing it right next to another computer. This kind of takes away from the fun atmosphere of multi-player. But is there any difference between 3 and Full Burst? I don't really think there is. Overall, it's a great and addictive game, but I'd price it at maybe $15-$25, I'm not sure it's worth the full $40.

												I don't like Naruto. I am not a big fighting game fan. I only bought it because it was on sale.... and I don't regret it for once o.o.Pros:-The story was very cohesive and actually well paced (i know...story in a fighting game. Who would have thought).  I actually enjoyed the story -The controls are surprizingly good if you use the controller. - Somewhat of an open world feeling. I guess after you beat story mode, you can walk around the ninja world and do side quests (some which are very entertaining)Cons: -if you are an hardcore fighting gamer you might be disappointed. No tricky combos. Plays more like Super smash brothers. -cut scenes can go on forever-no real tutorial so you just have to figure out how to do a lot of the actions yourself (tips in the loading screens help)Don't judge this game by the title. It isn't utter♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Its a solid 7.5/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Let me preface this review by saying I do not watch this or any Chinese cartoons, but from what I can gather through the story is that it's an animated version of Brokeback Mountain where there is too many characters with very colourful magical spells. Also, ignore the few number of hours I've spent on the game because I played it on a friend's PS3. By "played" I mean marathoning the entire story in a night.-----------------------------------------------As much as I can't stomach the whole "power of friendship" vibe present in this game, I can't deny that the story wasn't awesome despite the absolute disregard for the laws of motion and absence of gravity. You'll have fun in the campaigns as long as you don't ask too many questions and just accept the convoluted rainbow of homo-erotic references and tentacles as a cornerstone of any game coming out of Japan. You essentially rescind all rights to question the content of the game upon reading its title. Seriously, just read that title to yourself out loud.There's about 80 characters you can play as, most of them in the versus mode, the online matching which I haven't tried, but if the local versus is anything to go by it's a lot of fun to absolutely pummel the fecal matter out of your opponent with your magic spells.A steal when on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I bought this game to provide a summarised version of the events that took place during Shippuden. I found the anime took too long to progress with the main timeline, with 5 minute pauses of soliloquy which the manga managed to deal with in one page. This game does provide the core moments of Naruto with no filler "episodes", the only filler in this game could be the exploration aspect which seems a bit pointless, even collecting the items scattered across the area does not assist with battle which provides many points to purchase items. The battles are brilliantly orchestrated and animated. The fighting aspects/gameplay took me a while to grasp because this was my first Naruto game although after using the "substitute" feature the game is not that hard and often too simple but there are great battles here and they are really really well implemented, perhaps more exciting and intriguing than the anime. I would recommend this game to fans who have missed out on the Shippuden series and to fans who enjoyed the series and would like to relive the battles. I did feel unfufilled after completeing the campaign because of the many story elements left open. It would be great if they provided the option to play as the "bad" guys. I got a bit tired of the Naruto philosophy of peace and friendship because this is Shonen Jump after all, its very simplistic philosophy and its meant to promote some sort of sociatal norm of parenting, friendship, "why do you fight?", "to protect", "bleh", and side steps most of this arguments and tries to simplify some of it which made me wonder why I watch Naruto in the first place perhaps I want more from the relationship between Naruto, Sasuke and Sakura. I am not really interested in the other characters and therefore this anime just seems to be deviating from what makes it special....but anyway great game, pick it up if its on special but its more an interactive story than game but with great fights....really great fights

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												It's Just fun. I personally haven't even cared for naruto games since about what... Clash of ninja...  But this... It feels like someone took Dragonball Z Threw it on the floor and then smashed it with a gutted One Peice grand adventure.As far as battling goes, It's your run or the mill kaiblast spam enabled fighter where you can either sweat it out with actual skill or 200 Million volts amal virtually the whole game. It does feel less enabled to do that seeing as the moves are very easy to do and a flick of the stick an change to varying combos. So it is very VERY easy to look and enjoy the game visually without buggering about specific moves or getting traped into a bind or ai that refuses to stop spamming you into the dirt. It's just fun. And it's sad that is the easiest way I can describe this game.Just like most of the dragonball z series games, the game will give you the story while you play, though Naruto feels exponentially more immersive as to give you the mood and air of the moment while also letting you play, something that most attention to detail games like mass effect or such manage to so while you're playing. (or I really need to play newer games because a lot of newer games are just doing things right.) Nonetheless, instead of the normal something is about to happen here is what it is and a small flashback as to why, like sonic games and such. This game gives more of an RPG like place in the game, letting you observe details and characters from the beginning, and actively letting you use them, accompanied with allies who may have also been present. Long story short... It is really a great experience to be had.Experience wise. The potential and overall delivery of the game is probably the best part to me. The menus and interface, the overworld and different types of battles as well as a grand sum of characters does very well as a fan service  as well as a new game. Mob battles feel very much akin to games like dynasty warriors but multiplied by classic beat em ups. Small chechpointed areas and a fun way to see how your characters would work against everyone who isn't really a hero. It's beautifully presented, plays very smooth, and shows what the games can really become at any time provided people either ask for it or beg for a mod. It's hard to explain, But when you see two main characters and two assist characters on stage, it seems to really put up for some actual team battles. (Don't know if they exist) All in all, It's surely a good time and plays as good as it looks creative. Shoot me in the foot though, as I wish whoever is pushing the art for borderlands would flip a few tables over here, because I'm almost too sure that the series could look like a tearfully joyous creation provided their models went through some other sort of process... You know... where bloom isn't a thing? But I know that that will probably never happen and if it did... I'd need to get some depends. No points against it at all for that, or anything for that matter.I reccomend it for anyone who likes naruto or fighting games, open movement 3d fighting games to be specific, who also wanted to have rpg elements and unlockables along with scattered goodies that seperate it from normal fighting games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												The fourth Storm game in the Naruto Shippuden Ultimate Ninja Storm series, a dynamic and intense 3D fighting game set in the Naruto Universe as the name suggests, this game is purely made for the fans of the show and manga. It is faithful to both and has a large amount of characers to choose from and has beautiful cutscenes that top even the anime itself, thanks to it's visually impressive graphics. Though it's not without it's problems.The Story:The game begins with the Nine Tails demon fox attack on the Hidden Leaf Village (Konoha) and you get to play as memorable ninja like the Fourth Hokage Minato Namikaze and the Third Hokage Hiruzen Sarutobi. If these names sound unfamiliar to you then you haven't seen the show and thus won't really appreciate what this game has to offer, for it's story though it does attempt to bring newcomers in with the first mission fighting the tailed beast in an epic boss battle in the Leaf Village. After that the game fast forwards to a more recent timeline where our hero Naruto is renowned as the Hero of the village for defeating Pain in the previous game and has earnt everyone's respect. The game continues to tell the story in a open world-ish style where the player controls the characters and explores the world completing main story missions that contain very nicely done cutscenes, alot of talking and with some fights in between which really will please the Naruto fans with it's narrative newcomers will most likely be confused though, despite this the story mode is one of the best features in this game for me anyway.Gameplay:Naruto Storm 3 is a fighting game with many mechanics involved you can attack with strings of combos at the push of a button and moving the analogue stick (if your using a controller which is reccommended) up or down, you will get a different combo. You can use chakra to perform jutsu's and ultimate jutsu's which are flashy and over the top and is faithful to the characters, chakra can be used for dashing and enchancing shuriken throws.You can team up with two other support characters in team matches if you get tired of the single matches and this opens up new gameplay strategies, you can select what role your support characters can be such as support, defense and attack type. Each member can be summoned out and attack the opponent or called upon during a combo dash attack, once the team gauge is completely filled though you can perform a team ultimate jutsu combo, you can pick characters that work in a team in the show or completely make up your own team as there are loads to choose from. Although most of the characters use the same formula just with a different skin, each one has their own personal movesets and fighting style, making this game incredibly easy to just pick up and play which might turn off some professional fighting gamers.The boss battles are definitley a highlight in this game as they are both exciting and visually appealing it really shows how much time and effort the developers have put in to make these memorable fights epic, they even add some of their own cinematic fights in the game, such as extending the Naruto and Sasuke fight when they've reunited after Sasuke killed Danzo. The fights cutscenes are mostly QTE's but you do actually fight them like a normal match and the QTE's appear in certain moments of the fight, you are graded when completing the boss battles and it's satisfying to get an S rank on everyone of them.Another mode within the story campaign is the Mob battles which are similar to the Dynasty Warrior games, at certain points in the story mode you fight a mob of enemies and try to reach the goal this is an interesting element to the series, but the moments are short lived and there isn't that many which is dissapointing,.One last thing that Namco Bandai have added is the Ultimate Decision mode which allows the player to select decisions in the story, choosing Hero will result in an easier fight but with less rewards and experience to level up your item slots however Legend will have a harder fight but will have better rewards. The outcome doesn't matter that much but the fights themselves will change accordingly like in the Nine Tails attack you can choose to fight the Masked Man as Minato first, or fight the Nine Tails instead. Graphics: Naruto Storm games are known for having impressive and stunning visuals for it's graphics this really shows during the cutscenes, they aren't animated in fact they are full 3D models that are very detailed that contrast well with the colourful environments during the battles. Although the map is mostly scenery and window dressing even after the map has been blown up by Naruto's Tailed Beast Bomb ultimate jutsu, it even shows an explosion during the scene and somehow the environment remains untouched in future I would like a more dynamic battlefield,Sound:The music in this game although decent isn't very memorable I couldn't tell you what my favourite tracks were as I can with Payday 2, it's mostly repeated songs during fights and aren't very entertaining mostly piano symphonies if your into that kind of thing, which isn't to say it's bad just that you won't be downloading the soundtrack at anytime. Voice acting in English is fairly well done though I highly suggest playing Japanese voices. The sound effects themselves are great Naruto's Rasengan sounds like a Rasengan, Sasuke's Chidori sounds like how it should be you get the idea.Overall Naruto fans will love the story mode and the wide variety of familiar characters to choose from the game isn't completely up to date with the manga but it finishes off fairly close to where the anime left off at a certain point. I decided to review this game as the manga is ending within 5 weeks I hope you all enjoyed my review and will consider getting into the series, as it has it's action, comedy, interesting characters and some deep messages within for you to experience.Pros+Good storymode +Faithful visuals+Lots of characters +Many game modes +Easy to pick up and playCons- Laggy frame rate (though patch has improved it)- Hard to find a online game- Might put off fans of fighting games such as Street Fighter or Tekken for it's simpleness - Optimisation could be better

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Note: This review is only based on how good of a game it is in terms of it being good, not on it's money value.  I'm a veteran fan(sort of), I played Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm Generation.  This game surpasses it by a long shot. The story mode was 10/10.  It recreated all those emotional anime scenes with the game engine.  With beautiful visuals and graphics.  The music and the scenery had me feel like I was in the game and I was important to the story and the protection of the Hidden Leaf Village.  The free roam portion during the main story is cool.  Not much to say but that it's a nice factor.  Nothing really special about it.  One thing I liked were the very very challening fights when you picked Legend as the outcome.  I liked a good challenge and yeah I would die sometimes but it was a lot of fun.  The VS mode is back with a tiny upgrades.  It's more balanced then prevous titles like Generations.  The fighting style is unique.  It's not perfect to being fair 100% but it's close.  A huge roster of characters.  People say that they gave us characters that nobody even cares about.  That's not true, their fighting styles are all cool to try out.  The online was good.  Tournament was so much fun!  You could watch the battles of other players when it's not your turn.  The random battle conditions make it intense.  But some battle conditions just mean spam the ultimate jutsu until it lands and you win instantly.  I give this game a 10/10.  Beautiful game.  Only problems I've encountered is that sometimes the online can be laggy.  Just some minor problems with the net code is all.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												If you're a fan of Naruto and in the mood for some over the top craziness, this is the game for you. While not very challenging at all, the game does keep you engadged with some really cool reinterpretations straight from the anime/manga, accompanied by cutscenes and quicktime events. The battle system itself is very straight forward and easy to learn, though it's a shame that none of the AI opponents never really challenge you, which can make an otherwise awesome mechanic feel a little stale. Unfortunately, the multiplayer is unplayable, with de-syncs that stop the match every 2-3 seconds. That being said though, the local multiplayer is tons of fun, and where you can really experiment and mess around with the combat system.This is a great game for any naruto fan that wants to go back through the story, though with a little bit more interactivity, or for anyone looking for a great local multiplayer fighting game.

												This is a great game for any Naruto fan. It has a nice graphical style, and very cinematic battles. But the game has many flaws, mainly its combat system. The combat in this game lacks depth, though the community has addapted and made some creative strategies with support characters and combos. Also the cutscenes are VERY long, you'll spend 75% of the time at least watching cutscenes, you can skip them but they are important for the story. There are over 80 characters to pick from but they are pretty much the same mechanically, except for a few that stand out. Still, the story mode is fun, and it has online multiplayer with a ranking.

Obviously if you're a fan of Naruto, you will most likely like this game. Very good game indeed; I just wish they went farther into the storyline. But hey, that's what the next game "Ninja Storm Revolution" is for, right?8/10

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Awesome game! Even if you don't watch Naruto or aren't even an anime watcher, this game is a must-have for melee/action gamers. With this game, you can accustom yourself to a character (or a set of characters), master him/her, and show him/her off in online battle. Unlike traditional combat games such as Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat, this game makes action sequences more simple and complex at the same time. Instead of playing in the 2D format of the aforementioned games with specific button-pushing combos, this game offers combo diversity without having to remember a ton of sequences. In this game, you can just repeatedly press the melee button and choose which direction you want to send your opponent to, and it should send them flying off to the desired direction. Moreover, this game allows you to utilize the expense of special attack energy (in this case chakra). This chakra allows players to gather up energy and expend it in a variety of ways: ninjutsu (special attack), dash, strong shuriken throws, and etc. Manipulating energy in this fashion allows for more complex gameplay, whereas others games would force players to spam attacks in order to win a game. This and many other facets of the gameplay make this game a must-buy.

												Amazing game. Solid single player with again more upgrades compared to the older versions, and ofcourse pc quality graphics.The online seems to work smoothly ofcourse connecting to people who have a slow ISP will need more time to pick a character and load a map.As for combat itself, theres 4 keys. Melee / Ranged / Chakra / Dash.But its not as simple as that. chakra+melee = special / chakra chakra melee = ultimate and so on, you can combine chakra activations with attacks and movement.Also you can combine movements with attacks like holding down while tapping melee will result in a diffrent combo this will make your oponents timing on defending harder.And each character has a special ranged/melee combo wich can be accesed with forward forward melee how it is followed up depends on character you are usingMinor downside for me personally is that in single player fights some finishing moves involve buttons to be pressed in time or mashed wich distracts from the amazing jawdropping scenes running in the back.(sadly they have done this as long as ive played ultimate ninja games)

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Let me preface this review by saying I do not watch this or any Chinese cartoons, but from what I can gather through the story is that it's an animated version of Brokeback Mountain where there is too many characters with very colourful magical spells. Also, ignore the few number of hours I've spent on the game because I played it on a friend's PS3. By "played" I mean marathoning the entire story in a night.-----------------------------------------------As much as I can't stomach the whole "power of friendship" vibe present in this game, I can't deny that the story wasn't awesome despite the absolute disregard for the laws of motion and absence of gravity. You'll have fun in the campaigns as long as you don't ask too many questions and just accept the convoluted rainbow of homo-erotic references and tentacles as a cornerstone of any game coming out of Japan. You essentially rescind all rights to question the content of the game upon reading its title. Seriously, just read that title to yourself out loud.There's about 80 characters you can play as, most of them in the versus mode, the online matching which I haven't tried, but if the local versus is anything to go by it's a lot of fun to absolutely pummel the fecal matter out of your opponent with your magic spells.A steal when on sale.

												Fun as ♥♥♥♥, do not regret buying at all.Gets a bit grind-y and cutscene-y at times, but real tears were wept during both the confrontation between Sasuke and Naruto (strange, because I hate Sasuke with a passion) and the reunion with Kushina (where I actually had to take a break overnight the first time I hit it because too many feels).Story mode is kind of ehhh, I get that fighting games tend to be pretty railroady (especially when there's already an established canon) but handing down an S-rank♥♥♥♥♥whupping only to get a cutscene of the recipient brushing you off gets real old real fast.Other than that, my only gripes were that there weren't enough mob battles, and the only real ones were from Sasuke's POV (who I, as mentioned previously, despise utterly) and Darui's (who really gives a ♥♥♥♥ about Darui?) which was on a time limit to boot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31
												I was pleasantly surprised with this game, apart from a few annoyances in the story mode, and also now with Ninja Storm 4 being out, most people will be playing that multiplayer, so maybe you won't find random people to easily to play this with. But overall it was a good experience for me, and I felt it was worth it.Pros------- Decent combat system which is fun to master.- QTE Scenes from the story mode were the best part of the game.- Good transfer of the anime plot to a fighting game experience.- Lots of extra stuff in the game, especially the ability to do the historic fights from the previous games.Cons------- Game is split up into tons of loading screens.- Not a great port from console to pc overall, with bugs and performance issues.- Some frustrating moments in story mode that can't be skipped when redo-ing "Seventails" -_-- Interlude running sections between areas feel pointless.
